DNR OWNED ACCESS ON SOUTHWEST SHORE.  LAKE BENTON CITY LIMITS

surveys.narrative: Lake Benton, located in Lincoln County on the Minnesota-South Dakota border, is a class 41 lake. This 2,857-acre lake is managed primarily for walleye and secondarily for northern pike, black crappie, bluegill, and yellow perch. Lake Benton has had historical problems with curlyleaf pondweed (an exotic). Curlyleaf pondweed was not documented in a lake survey in 1983, however was documented in 1992. This prolific exotic macrophyte has caused problems with recreational boaters at certain times of the year and tends to choke out the native vegetation. Like most issues, there are positives and negatives with curlyleaf pondweed. It is possible that curlyleaf pondweed has created nursery area or additional spawning habitat for some species. Walleye fingerlings have not been stocked in Lake Benton since 1982 however fry have been stocked in 1983, 1985, 1988, 1990, 1991, 1993, 1994, 1998, and 2000. Walleye natural reproduction will be assessed in years not stocked. The average walleye catch rate was 36.60 fish/gill net. The catch rate for walleye was more than 2 times the upper average range (15.33 fish/gill net) for this lake class. Total lengths of walleye captured in gill nets ranged from 10.91 to 27.24 inches with a mean of 17.99 inches. The data indicates the population relative abundance was nearly the largest ever documented and in addition indicates a large size structure. Six seine hauls captured 2 Age 0 walleye which indicated either fry survival and/or natural reproduction. The "take-home" message is that good numbers and sizes of walleyes are available for anglers. Some local anglers and bait dealers have said fishing has never been better. The average northern pike population catch rate was 0.60 fish/gill net. The catch rate for northern pike in gill nets was half the lower average range (1.20 fish/gill net) for this lake class. Historical gill net catches for northern pike have never been higher than the average range (3.5 fish/gill net) which is indicative of a low density population. The northern pike catch rate in trap nets (0.15 fish/trap net) further indicate this low density population. Data from the 1992 survey judged spawning habitat for northern pike to be "fair" because of wetlands accessability. The average yellow perch population catch rate was 73.40 fish/gill net. The catch rate of yellow perch was largest ever documented on Lake Benton and was more than 3 times the 75% quartile (22.50 fish/gill net) for this lake class. Total lengths of yellow perch captured in gill nets ranged from 5.16 to 11.97 inches with a mean of 7.14 inches. Most of the fish were from the 1997 (36%), 1998 (27%), and the 1999 (34%) year classes. Six seine hauls produced 39 Age 0 yellow perch which indicated some natural reproduction in 2000. Some great perch fishing can be had during the winter of 2000-2001 but the next few years could be phenomenal. The average black crappie population catch rate was 1.85 fish/trap net. The catch rate of black crappie in trap nets was less than the upper average range (1.85 fish/trap net) for this lake class. Total lengths of black crappie caught in trap nets ranged from 5.16 to 12.24 inches with a mean of 9.47 inches. The average bluegill trap net catch rate was 0.38 fish/trap net. The catch rate for bluegill in trap nets was less than the lower average range (0.38 fish/trap net) for this lake class. The average black bullhead gill net catch rate was 83.20 fish/gill net. The catch rate for black bullhead in gill nets was the largest ever recorded on Lake Benton and slightly higher than the upper average range (83.00 fish/gill net) for this lake class. The average black bullhead trap net catch rate was 45.85 fish/trap net. The catch rate for black bullhead in trap nets in 2000 was the second highest catch ever recorded on Lake Benton and was greater than the average range (14.73 fish/trap net) for this lake class. The data suggests a high density black bullhead population with a relatively large size structure is present compared to other area lakes. Good action could be had with an occasional "trophy" being caught. This population provides a good chance to teach kids how to fish because of the action provided by this population. The average common carp trap net catch rate was 4.92 fish/trap net. Total lengths of common carp captured in trap nets ranged from 14.53 to 30.31 inches with a mean of 21.15 inches. The average common carp gill net catch rate was 0 fish/gill net. This data indicates that common carp might not be captured easily with the use of gill nets in Lake Benton. This population might provide a unique situation for some real large carp to be caught. To promote and maintain healthy fish populations, pollution and other inputs need to be controlled. Fish habitats are directly affected by water quality. Nutrient, sediment and other waste inputs can drastically alter the biological, chemical, and physical components of a lake. It is paramount to maintain if not improve the current water quality of Lake Benton through watershed management to preserve this fishery for future generations to enjoy.

Benton is a 2,875 acre lake which is located in the city of Lake Benton in Lincoln County. The lake has 18.1 miles of shoreline and a maximum depth of nine feet. Benton is presently managed for walleye as the primary species while northern pike, yellow perch, bluegill, and black crappie are managed secondarily. The curlyleaf pondweed stand which appeared in the 1980's has expanded to eventually become the focal point of concern in the city of Lake Benton and around the lake itself. A group was formed to study ways to eradicate the curlyleaf from Lake Benton. Although this particular exotic plant has social and biological drawbacks, it contributes to improved water quality and a diverse, relatively stable fish population like none other in Southwestern Minnesota. A creel survey conducted during the 1996 open-water season and the 1996-97 winter season documented Lake Benton's importance as a regional fishing and tourist destination. Total estimated fishing pressure was 13.4 angler hours per acre, a figure comparable to that found statewide for lakes less than 100,000 acres. The economic value of this fishery during the 1996 season was estimated to be approximately $670,000, much of which is money spent in the immediate area.The walleye population looks in good shape for lakes similar to Lake Benton. Lengths of walleye caught in our nets ranged from 8.3 to 24.6 inches and averaged 22.0 inches. Seven different age groups of walleye were observed during our assessment from age 1 to age 9. We presently stock walleye fry every other year and it is apparent that the curlyleaf stand offers a place for the small fish to hide so they have better survival than in lakes with no vegetation.The yellow perch population is similar to other lakes like Lake Benton. Lengths of yellow perch caught in our nets ranged from 6.2 to 9.2 inches and averaged 8.0 inches.The northern pike population also looks good for lakes similar to Lake Benton. Lengths of northern pike caught in our nets ranged from 18.7 to 38.6 inches and averaged 29.3 inches. Half of the fish sampled in trap nets were 35 inches or longer.If you're looking for trophy bluegill in Southwest Minnesota, Lake Benton may be the lake for you to try. The numbers are about average for lakes similar to Lake Benton but several of the fish were 12 inches or longer. Lengths ranged from 4.6 to 13.2 inches and averaged 10.3 inches. As with the walleye population, it appears the curlyleaf stand also benefits the bluegill population.The black crappie population is similar to other lakes like Lake Benton. Lenghts of black crappie caught in our nets ranged from 7.2 to 11.2 inches and averaged 7.9 inches. Only age 2 black crappie were sampled during the assessment.Other species of fish caught in our nets included common carp and white suckers.To promote and maintain healthy fish populations, pollution and other inputs need to be controlled. Fish habitats are directly affected by water quality. Nutrient, sediment and other waste inputs can drastically alter the biological, chemical, and physical components of a lake. It is important to maintain if not improve the current water quality of Lake Benton through watershed management to preserve this fishery for future generations to enjoy.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre shallow lake located in Lincoln County nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border and adjacent to the city of Lake Benton. Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 ft, a 10 year average water clarity of 1.8 feet (range = 0.5-2.5), and at times supports vegetation to 8 feet. Recently, vegetation is sparse and is composed of native species (sago and coontail) with some patches of invasive curly leaf pondweed on the north end of the lake. Curly leaf pondweed was at one time very prolific and covered nearly 100% of the surface water. After Floridone chemical treatments from 2005 to 2009 and again in 2017, comparatively the lake has been nearly devoid of curly leaf pondweed. A population assessment was conducted the week of July 31st, 2017 with 6 gill nets and 15 trap nets to assess the managed fish species.

WALLEYE
Two hundred and seventeen Walleye were caught in the fish netting assessment. The gillnet catch rate of 26.8 per net exceeded the normal range for similar lakes. Additionally, the catch rate exceeds the long-term average of 23.1 per gillnet. While the catch rate of Walleye is high compared to past surveys, the size structure of Walleye is less than desired in the short term. The average length of Walleyes caught was just over 13 inches in gill nets and just shy of 11 inches in trap nets with a range of 7.7 to 26.1 inches. Walleye are currently dominated by 1-year-old and 2-year-old fish making up 88% of the sample and corresponds to stocked years. But, on the bright side, natural reproduction does occur frequently on Lake Benton and has been found in each non-stocked year starting in 2008 (2008, 2011, 2014, and 2017). Occasionally natural reproduction does result in strong year classes that adds to the fishery. Currently, anglers should expect to catch many small Walleyes which could result in some good action. However, growth in Lake Benton is good so harvestable Walleye will be caught by next year.

NORTHERN PIKE
Six Northern Pike were caught in gillnets and trap nets in 2017. The gillnet catch rate of 0.5 per net was less than the normal range for similar lakes statewide, but within the Windom Area normal range. Windom Area lakes typically have low abundance Northern Pike populations due to degraded habitat for spawning (low aquatic vegetation density), for predation (low visibility water), and for thermal requirements (hot summer water temperatures). However, at times, Lake Benton can have a decent population of Northern Pike, usually a result of stocking. The Northern Pike abundance in Lake Benton will continue to be low, however, the new southern zone regulation of 2 daily with a 24 inch minimum size starting in May 2018 may stabilize the Northern Pike population.

YELLOW PERCH
Over 500 Yellow Perch were sampled in gillnets and trap nets in 2017. The gillnet catch rate of 87.3 per net is the second highest ever recorded and the highest since 2006. The size structure of the Yellow Perch was good with an average length of 8.5 inches in gill nets with a possibility to catch fish all the way up to 13 inches. The physical condition of the Yellow Perch was excellent with plump fish common. Currently, the Lake Benton Yellow Perch population is healthy with many harvestable sized fish out there!

BLACK CRAPPIE
Only 10 Black Crappie were caught in gillnets and trap nets. The trap net abundance of 0.5 per net is less than the normal range for similar lakes. Black Crappie have had a catch rate less than the normal range since 2013. Black Crappie are stocked sporadically by the Lake Benton Sports Club to maintain a population.

BLUEGILL
Only 8 Bluegill were caught in gillnets and trap nets. The trap net catch rate of 0.5 per net is less than the normal range for similar lakes. As with Black Crappie, Bluegill are a low abundance population that is stocked sporadically by the Lake Benton Sports Club. Future efforts to maintain Bluegill will also be reliant on the club to continue stocking as the Windom Area Fisheries will not stock Bluegill due to lack of desirable habitat.

OTHER SPECIES
Other species sampled in Lake Benton in 2017 were Black Bullhead, Common Carp, Green Sunfish, Largemouth Bass, and White Sucker. Black Bullhead, Common Carp, and White Sucker numbers are all within or greater than normal ranges for each species. Black Bullhead and Common Carp are species that lead to habitat degradation through resuspension of benthic sediments. However, murky water can be beneficial for Walleye but too many Black Bullhead and Common Carp are detrimental to all species. Green Sunfish and Largemouth Bass are in very low abundance and may be utilizing limited habitat that will likely continue to suppress their abundance as is the case with Bluegill in Lake Benton.

Lake Benton is a nearly 3,000 acre lake located in Lincoln County nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border and adjacent to the city of Lake Benton. Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 ft, fairly murky water (10 year summer average water clarity of 1.8 feet), and at times supports vegetation to 8 feet. Recently, native vegetation is sparse and is composed of sago pond weed and coontail. Invasive curly-leaf pondweed does occur from time-to-time and is found more recently on the east end of the lake. Curly-leaf pondweed was at one time very prolific and covered nearly 100% of the surface water. Chemical treatment by Lincoln County from 2005 to 2009 virtually eliminated the actively growing plants until 2018 when it re-emerged likely via dormant seedbank in the sediment lake bottom. Treatment was utilized again in 2019 on the east end and has helped to temporarily keep the invasive curly-leaf pondweed at bay.

The lake is primarily managed and stocked every other year with Walleye. Other species stocked and managed are Northern Pike and Yellow Perch, however, they are only stocked when needed to boost the population. Fish netting was conducted during the week of July 29th, 2019 with 5 gill nets and 15 trap nets to assess Walleye, Northern Pike, and Yellow Perch.

WALLEYE
Just under 180 Walleye were caught in gillnets and trap nets. The gillnet catch rate of 27.6 per net was more than expected. Additionally, the catch rate was higher than the long-term average (17 surveys since 1956) of 23.4 per gillnet. The length of Walleye in Lake Benton improved since the 2015 and 2017 lake surveys. Just over half of the Walleye in the sample were between 15 and 20 inches with fish caught up to 27 inches. The overall health of each fish was good. The 2016 (age-3) and 2018 (age-1) stocked years made up 90% of the sample. Additionally, an encouraging point is that natural reproduction does occur frequently on Lake Benton and has been found in each non-stocked year since 2008. Occasionally natural reproduction does result in strong year classes that adds to the fishery. Lower Mississippi Strain Walleye (LMS Walleye, Lake Sarah Egg Take) are being utilized during fry stocking (every other year) to increase the potential of natural reproduction in the future due to the success of LMS Walleye in other southern Minnesota Lakes. Several more year classes of Walleye in Lake Benton would be beneficial to continue the rebound that has been observed since 2015. To ensure that, Walleye numbers will be monitored closely with another Lake survey in 2021. Currently, the Walleye population will provide an excellent fishing opportunity with 2 very strong year classes of Walleye that range from 12.5 inches to 20.5 inches.

NORTHERN PIKE
More Northern Pike were caught in gillnets and trap nets in 2019 than expected. The gillnet catch of just under 2 per net was within the normal range for similar lakes statewide but was more than other Windom Area lakes. Windom Area lakes typically have low abundance Northern Pike populations due to degraded habitat for spawning (low aquatic vegetation density), for predation (high turbidity), and for water temperature (80 plus Fahrenheit summer water temperatures). Lake Benton does have a decent population of Northern Pike from time-to-time. This was the case in 2019. The gill net catch was the 2nd highest on record and the trap net catch rate was above the long-term average. The Northern Pike abundance in Lake Benton appears to be improving. This could be due to the new southern zone regulation (2 daily limit with a 24 inch minimum size) that started in 2018. Additionally, our high water years the last three years could have improved Northern Pike spawning habitat either in Lake Benton or adjacent wetlands. The population will be monitored to determine if the regulation is increasing the population or if improving habitat may be responsible.

YELLOW PERCH
Many Yellow Perch were sampled in gillnets and trap nets in 2019. The gillnet catch rate of 72.6 per net is the fourth highest ever recorded. The size of the Yellow Perch in the measured sample was good. The average length of Yellow Perch was just over 9.5 inches in gill nets and just under 6 inches in trap nets with a range from 4.5 to 12.5 inches. The physical condition of the Yellow Perch was good indicating plump fish that are finding enough to eat. Currently, the Lake Benton Yellow Perch population is balanced and has larger fish that should entice anglers.

OTHER SPECIES
Other species sampled in Lake Benton in 2017 were Bluegill, Black Crappie, Black Bullhead, Common Carp, Green Sunfish, Orangespotted Sunfish, and White Sucker. Bluegill, Black Crappie, Black Bullhead, Common Carp, and White Sucker numbers are all within or more than expected ranges for each species. Black Bullhead and Common Carp are species that lead to habitat degradation through resuspension of muck and sediment. Green Sunfish and Orangespotted Sunfish were found in low abundance and were limited to nearshore rocky habitat.

WALLEYE POPULATION IS TEN TIMES THE STATE AVERAGE WITH 17.6 TIMES THE AVERAGE PDS PER GILL NET SET. 10% ARE FROM AGE GROUP I, WITH THE BALANCE FROM GROUP IV; ALL ARE THE RESULT OF TWO FRY STOCKING. GROWTH RATE IS FAST. NORTHERN PIKE NUMBERS WERE BELOW AVERAGE IN THE GILL NET SETS, BUT THREE TIMES ABOVE IN TRAP NETS. GROWTH IS FAST AFTER THE FIRST YEAR. BLACK CRAPPIE NUMBERS ARE OVER FOUR TIMES STATE AVERAGE AND SHOW FAST GROWTH. 69% ARE AGE II AND II, WITH GOOD AVERAGE SIZE. THE BLUE- GILL POPULATION IS ALSO OVER FOUR TIMES STATE AVG WITH SIX AGE GROUPS REPRESENTED. GROWTH IS GOOD. YELLOW PERCH NUMBERS ARE SEVERAL TIMES STATE AVG WITH GOOD AVG SIZE AND GROWTH RATE. YEAR CLASSES I, II, AND III AND WELL REPRESENTED. PUMPKINSEED AND HYBIRD SUNFISH ARE PRESENT IN SMALLER NUMBERS, THOUGH STILL OVER STATE AVG. GROWTH IS GOOD. AERA- TION SYSTEM AND IMPROVED VEGETATIVE COVER SHOULD IMPROVE SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION FOR MOST SPECIES. BLACK BULLHEAD NUMBERS ARE TEN TIMES AVG, BUT AVG SIZE AND CONDITIONS ARE GOOD. A FEW LARGE WHITE SUCKERS ARE PRESENT, BUT NO CARP OR BUFFALO WERE TAKEN IN THE SURVEY.

Lake Benton is located in Lincoln County on the Minnesota-South Dakota border. This 2,857-acre lake is managed primarily for walleye and secondarily for northern pike, black crappie, bluegill, and yellow perch. Curlyleaf pondweed has been the focus of much attention in the last few years. Curlyleaf pondweed was not documented in a lake survey in 1983, however was documented in 1992. This prolific exotic macrophyte has been perceived as negatively impacting the resource by limiting native aquatic vegetation and recreational boating at certain times of the year. Curlyleaf pondweed was not documented in a lake survey in 1983, however it was found in 1992. In the first year of a 3-5 year trial, 2 experimental whole lake treatments using fluridone were initiated in 2005 to reduce curlyleaf pondweed to manageable levels. As a result of this experimental treatment, the Windom Area Office will monitor the fish community for the next three years to document the potential effects of fluridone. Currently, walleye fry are to be stocked two out of three years at 1000 walleye/ littoral acre. A population assessment was conducted during the week of July 18, 2005 using 6 gill nets and 13 trap nets.The walleye catch rate in gill nets was the lowest catch rate ever documented by DNR netting. The average length walleye was just over 17 inches. Despite the low catch rate in gill nets, the catch rate in trap nets, which was greater than expected. On a positive note, several walleyes were captured from the fry stocking in 2005, which may indicate good fry survival. Much of the information collected suggested the larger sized walleye are in slightly better condition, which could be a result of the large numbers of small bullheads available as forage. It is possible that the Lake Benton walleye population is in a building cycle and could provide some great fishing once the bullhead numbers begin to decline.The northern pike population has never been abundant, but usually the fish are quite healthy and good sized. They averaged 27 inches and age analysis indicates they resulted from natural reproduction in 2001 and 2002. The Windom Area pike populations can vary as a result of habitat conditions at the time of spawning. Northern pike need water level and environmental conditions to be right in order for them to be successful in spawning. It is our belief that northern pike fingerling stockings will provide a secondary predator for the fish community and provide some angling opportunities. In an effort to build the population, northern pike fingerlings will be stocked in the spring of 2006 at a rate of 5 fingerlings/acre. Yellow perch numbers were lower than desired. The catch rate for yellow perch was 1.8 fish/gill net, which was below average. Total lengths of yellow perch captured ranged from 6 to 10 inches and averaged just over 8 inches. Due to the lack of smaller yellow perch sampled, it is likely that the large black bullhead population may be impacting natural reproduction of yellow perch. Efforts to control black bullhead numbers will likely benefit the yellow perch population. A few "10-inchers" can be caught if an angler is willing to put the time in. However, if perch are your target, West Twin Lake might be a better option for your angling hours.Black crappie population numbers have not changed substantially over the last 10 years. Total lengths of black crappie caught in trap nets ranged from 7 to 12 inches and averaged almost 9 inches. Although the numbers of crappie are not exceedingly high, some "slabs" can be caught. If "crappie" is your targeted species, Lake Shetek has good numbers them.Bluegill numbers are not real high but these populations can change quickly. Given the large mats of curlyleaf pondweed in Lake Benton, it is quite possible that within a year or two the population can change substantially due to the habitat conditions. However, the shallow basins in the pothole prairie region challenge bluegill populations due to wind action affecting spawning nests and water clarity. Lake Benton has a history of producing some real trophy bluegills if you can find them.The black bullhead population is dominating the fish community in Lake Benton. Unfortunately, many of the fish are not going to be "keepers". Total lengths ranged from 5.9 to 13.3 inches with an average of 6.5 inches. Trap nets did sample some larger (11-13 inch range) bullheads but overall caught mainly smaller fish. There is no doubt that this population will provide some good action for fishing if you are looking to spend some time outdoors. This might be a good opportunity to teach kids how to fish and at the same time keep them interested in the activity by catching some fish.To promote and maintain healthy fish populations, pollution and other inputs need to be controlled. Fish habitats are directly affected by water quality. Nutrient, sediment and other waste inputs can drastically alter the biological, chemical, and physical components of a lake. It is paramount to maintain if not improve the current water quality of Lake Benton through watershed management to preserve this fishery for future generations to enjoy. Other species captured were common carp, largemouth bass, white crappie, and white sucker.Prepared by Ryan Doorenbos

In conjunction with a standard gill net and trap net survey on Lake Benton in 2017, a nearshore survey was conducted. Twenty-four sampling stations, located around the perimeter of Lake Benton, were sampled with backpack electrofishing and shoreline seining. Ten species of fish were sampled. Species included Black Bullhead, Black Crappie, Brook Stickleback, Common Carp, Fathead Minnow, Green Sunfish, Iowa Darter, Johnny Darter, White Sucker, and Yellow Perch. A previous nearshore survey was done in 2011 and had all the same species as 2017 with the exception of Brook Stickleback, and had 4 additional species. The 4 additional species in 2011 were Bluntnose Minnow, Bigmouth Buffalo, Bluegill, and Orangespotted Sunfish. While the 2017 nearshore survey was a reduction in the diversity of species observed, there was 1 new species (Brook Stickleback) and many young-of-the-year present. Young-of-the-year species included Black Bullhead, Black Crappie, Common Carp, Fathead Minnow, and White Sucker indicating good natural reproduction for each of those species. The species diversity in the 2017 nearshore survey along with the species diversity in the standard gill net and trap net survey will be utilized to develop an index to assess biotic integrity of Lake Benton. The index will be utilized to address potential watershed issues that could be fixed to improve conditions for the fish community.

An assessment of lakeshore habitat on Lake Benton was conducted on 8/7/2017. The assessment consisted of 73 survey sites evenly spaced 400 meters around the lake. The average lake wide habitat score was 65.5(+/- 2.8), indicating overall lakeshore habitat quality was low (50-65). Sites with low habitat quality are typically developed and have a lower than expected amount of natural habitat. Vegetation has been removed from at least a portion of the shore frontage either in a small percent of all the canopy layers or from a large percent of at least one canopy layer (ex. shrub layer has been removed but trees and natural ground cover remain high). Approximately 50 percent of the sites were developed with a mean score of 46.6(+/- 2.7), while undeveloped sites had a mean score of 84.8(+/- 2.2). This habitat survey was designed to provide a means to quantify and compare lakeshore habitat between lakes. The Lake Benton shoreline habitat score is lower than the statewide lake score average of 73.6.

Prepared by Nate Hodgins

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre, class 41 lake that is adjacent to the City of Lake Benton in Lincoln County. Lake Benton is managed primarily for Walleye and secondarily for Yellow Perch, Northern Pike, Black Crappie, and Bluegill. Walleye are stocked every other year at Lake Benton, which allows for assessment of natural reproduction in non-stocked years. Walleye were not stocked in 2020 because of the COVID-19 pandemic, so Walleye were stocked in 2021 despite being an "off" year. A Walleye fry stocking evaluation using daytime electrofishing was conducted on September 21, 2021 to determine if the 2021 fry stocking was successful.

Young-of-the-year Walleye were captured at a rate of 304.0 per hour, which indicates that the fry stocking was successful, natural reproduction occurred, or a combination of the two. Genetic analysis showed that over 90 percent of the YOY Walleye were from stocking. Walleye fingerlings ranged in length from 4.8 to 7.3 inches and averaged 5.7 inches. The 2021 year class is abundant and should be important in the Lake Benton Walleye population for years to come.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre shallow windswept lake located in Lincoln County nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border and adjacent to the city of Lake Benton. Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 feet, a 10 year average summer water clarity of 1.7 feet (range = 0.5-2.5), and at times supports vegetation to 8 feet. The clarity reading was 1.0 in 2021 with reduced maximum depth to 8 feet as a result of recent drought conditions. Recently, both submergent and emergent vegetation is sparse. The native submergent composition is sago and coontail and invasive curly-leaf pondweed on the east end of the lake. Curly-leaf pondweed was at one time very prolific and covered nearly 100% of the surface water. Herbicidal treatment (Fluridone) done by Lincoln County from 2005 to 2009 virtually eliminated the plant until 2018 when it re-emerged. Low dose Fluridone was utilized again by Lincoln County in 2019 on the east end and has helped to keep the curly-leaf at a lower density.

The lake is primarily managed for Walleye and secondarily for Black Crappie, Bluegill, Northern Pike, and Yellow Perch. A population assessment was conducted the week of August 2nd, 2021 with 5 gill nets and 15 trap nets to assess the managed fish species.

WALLEYE
Fifty-one Walleye were caught in 5 gillnets (N=41) and 15 trap nets (N=10). The gillnet catch rate of 8.2 per net is within the expected catch range for similar lakes. However, the catch rate is less than the long-term average of 22.5 per gillnet. This may be a result of angler harvest due to very successful angling since 2019 as well as the increase in Common Carp caught in the gill net sample (69.8 per gillnet!). Common Carp tend clog the net with their dorsal and anal spines leaving little room for other species to be caught effectively. With that said, the size structure of Walleye continues to improve from 2015 to present. The vast majority of the Walleye in the sample were over 15 inches but less than 20 inches, with most fish in average body condition. Walleye are currently dominated by the 2016 (age 5-Spicer Strain) and 2018 (age 3-Lower Mississippi Strain, LMS) year classes making up 71% of the aged fish sample, both fry stocked years, resulting in many fish ranging in length from 16 to 25 inches. However, an encouraging point is that natural reproduction (LMS strain) does occur frequently on Lake Benton and has been found in each non-stocked year starting in 2008 (2008, 2011, 2014, 2017, 2019, and 2020). Occasionally natural reproduction does result in strong year classes that adds to the fishery. Currently, Lake Benton is stocked every other year with Walleye fry at a density of 500 fry per acre (N= 1,470,000 total) to observe natural reproduction in non-stocked years. Lower Mississippi Strain Walleye (Lake Sarah spawn take) are being utilized during fry stocking to increase the potential of natural reproduction in the future due to the success of LMS Walleye in other southern Minnesota Lakes. Encouragingly, a strong stocked year class appears to have resulted in 2021 with newly stocked fish showing up in the summer netting sample as well as the fall night electrofishing sample (catch rate of 304 per hour!). Currently, the Lake Benton Walleye population is poised to provide a good fishing opportunity due to 2 very strong year classes of Walleye that range from 16 inches to 25 inches. Additionally, the strong 2021 year class should continue the rebound that has been observed since 2015.

NORTHERN PIKE
Forty-seven Northern Pike were caught in gillnets (N=15) and trap nets (N=32) in 2021, an increase from 20 caught in 2019. The gillnet catch rate of 3.0 per net exceeded the Windom Area upper normal limit of 1.3 for similar lakes. Windom Area lakes typically have low abundance Northern Pike populations due to degraded habitat for spawning (low aquatic vegetation density), for predation (high turbidity), and for thermal requirements (80 plus degree F summer water temperatures). However, at times like in 2019 and 2021, Lake Benton can have a decent population of Northern Pike. The 2021 gill net catch rate was the greatest on record and the trap net catch rate was nearly 3 times greater than the long-term average of 0.6 per net. The Northern Pike abundance in Lake Benton appears to be improving. This could be due to the new southern zone regulation of 2 daily limit with a 24 inch minimum size that could be protecting the adult population. In 2021, 83% of the Northern Pike in the sample were less than 24 inches. Northern Pike in the gill net sample ranged from 16.9 to 24.7 inches and ranged from 17.3 to 34.5 inches in the trap net sample. The population will be monitored to determine if the regulation is increasing the population size distribution or determine if improving habitat may be responsible for the increase in reproduction. Additionally, important spawning areas for Northern Pike could be identified and protected in order to help stabilize the population. This would be a benefit not only to Norther Pike anglers, but would help to increase the abundance of a predator for young Common Carp.

YELLOW PERCH
Thirty-two Yellow Perch were sampled in gillnets (N=27) and trap nets (N=5) in 2021, down substantially from 2017 and 2019 catches. The gillnet catch rate of 5.4 per net is below the long term average of 48.5 per net, but within the normal range of 3.0 to 22.5 per net for similar lakes. The size structure of the Yellow Perch in the measured sample was good. The average length of Yellow Perch was 8.0 inches in gill nets and 5.7 inches in trap nets with a range from 5.4 to 13.0 inches. The physical condition of the Yellow Perch was good. Currently, the Lake Benton Yellow Perch population is within a normal abundance level with a balanced size distribution and some larger fish. These adult fish should have the potential produce future year classes of Yellow Perch if habitat is present (flooded downed trees and branches along the shoreline).

BLACK CRAPPIE
Ninety-seven Black Crappie were caught in gillnets (N=37) and trap nets (N=60) in 2021. The trap net catch of 4.0 per net is within the normal range of 1.0 to 12.3 for similar lakes. Black Crappie are sporadic in Lake Benton. In 2019, the trap net catch rate was high at 11.9 per net, but the size distribution favored small fish less than 8 inches. In 2021, it was apparent that the growth of Black Crappie was good over the course of 2 years with fish ranging from 5 to just under 13 inches. The average length of Black Crappie in the trap net sample was just over 10 inches and is a net type that best samples Black Crappie. Black Crappie are stocked sporadically by the Lake Benton Sports Club to maintain a population.

BLUEGILL
Only 2 Bluegill, 7.5 and 8.5 inches, were caught in trap nets in 2021. The trap net catch rate of 0.13 per net is less than the normal range of 1.1 to 14.9 per net for similar lakes. As with Black Crappie, the Bluegill population is sporadic and private stocking by the Lake Benton Sports Club is what helps maintain the population.

OTHER SPECIES
Other species sampled in Lake Benton in 2021 were Black Bullhead (N=229 in gill nets and N=374 in trap nets), Common Carp (N= 349 in gill nets and N=726 in trap nets), and White Sucker (N=26 in gill nets and N=4 in trap nets). Black Bullhead and White Sucker numbers were observed within normal ranges for each species. Common Carp numbers were well above what was expected for the species, and the greatest ever observed on Lake Benton. This was highly unusual, and occurred during a time where dead Common Carp were starting to appear along the shoreline. During August through October 2021 on Lake Benton there was a confirmed Carp Edema Virus (CEV) outbreak on the lake that resulted in a mass mortality limited to only Common Carp. This should reduce numbers of Common Carp back to more typical levels. Continued monitoring will be crucial to determine extent of the CEV related kill. Common Carp, along with Black Bullhead, are species that can lead to habitat degradation through resuspension of benthic sediments. Surveys since 2017 have indicated high abundances of each species, and given the CEV kill in 2021, there is reason to believe that the lake will experience reduced resuspension of sediments as a result of a potentially declining Common Carp population. A fisheries survey will be conducted during the summer of 2023 to determine the extent of the Common Carp kill and whether any improvements in Lake Clarity have resulted. In the meantime, a close eye will be given to Lake Benton to track and monitor any future Common Carp CEV outbreaks and potential kills.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre class 41 lake located in Lincoln County nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border. Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 feet, water clarity that rarely exceeds 2.5 feet in mid-summer, and in some years there is vegetation growth in depths to 8 feet. In recent years though, vegetation is sparse with very few plants growing. Curly-leaf pondweed was at one time very prolific and covered nearly 100% of the surface water from the mid-1990's up to the mid-2000's. Lakewide herbicide treatment (Fluridone) from 2005 to 2009 by Lincoln County nearly eliminated the plant until 2018 when it re-emerged. Low dose Fluridone was utilized again by Lincoln County in 2019 on the east end, helping to keep the curly-leaf at a low density.
The lake is primarily managed for Walleye and secondarily for Black Crappie, Bluegill, Northern Pike, and Yellow Perch. A fish assessment was conducted the week of July 24th, 2023 with 5 gill nets and 15 trap nets to assess the managed fish species.

WALLEYE

Lake Benton, at times, can be an angling destination to pursue Walleye. Since 2010, the gill net catch rates during summer surveys has been above the current long-range average of 22.6 Walleye per gill net, except for 2021 when it dipped to 8.20 per gill net. The low catch rate of Walleye in 2021 was most likely due to a massive catch of Common Carp filling up the gill net. Nonetheless, the average catch rate in Lake Benton has typically been greater than the 75% quartile for class 41 lakes in Minnesota (15.33 per gill net). In other words, Lake Benton is a Walleye factory! In 2023, the gill net catch rate remained above the long-term average with a catch rate of 24.8 per gill net. Ten different ages (ages 0-5, 7-9, and 12) of Walleye were present in the 2023 sample with ages 1, 2, and 3 being the most abundant representing 80% of all aged fish combined. Walleye ranged in length from 4.5 to 27 inches with a mean length of just under 15 inches in gill nets and 9.5 inches in trap nets. While the Walleye population is dominated by smaller, younger fish, 39% of Walleye in the gill net sample were over 15 inches. Anglers tend to prefer harvesting Walleye over 15 inches, and Lake Benton has a decent opportunity to encounter harvestable Walleye. Walleye in Lake Benton are healthy with a balanced size structure and harvestable fish available now. Growth of Walleye and overall relative abundance appears adequate to sustain Walleye into the near future.

BLACK CRAPPIE

Angling for Black Crappie is extremely popular in Minnesota, and the Lake Benton Sportsman's Club has an interest in maintaining a fishable crappie population in Lake Benton. The Lake Benton Sportsman's Club regularly applies for a permit from the Minnesota DNR to stock Black Crappie in Lake Benton. Black Crappie were last purchased in 2020 by The Lake Benton Sportsman's Club and a private supplier stocked 200 adult fish. When stocking Black Crappie it is important to stock adults prior to spring spawning so they can potentially boost the population via spawning in the same year, either within stocked fish or adding to spawning among the existing population. Since 2019, Black Crappie abundance has been above the long-term trap net average of 3.44 per trap net. In 2023, the trap net catch rate was 7.0 per net. Additionally, the gill net catch rate was 5.2 per net. The size structure of Black Crappie caught in gill nets and trap nets in 2023 favored larger fish over 10 inches. Two main size groups of Black Crappie were observed in trap nets, fish in the 5.5-7.5 inch range and fish over 10 inches. Black Crappie angling could be very good over the next several years with many 11-13 inch fish harvested.

BLUEGILL

Bluegill are another secondary management species in Lake Benton. Bluegill are relatively rare in Lake Benton as habitat is not conducive to high survival. Bluegill have not exceeded the long-term trap net catch rate of 4.8 per net since 1996 which was the same time period when Curly-leaf Pondweed covered most of Lake Benton. Bluegill abundance and aquatic vegetation are closely linked. The catch rate of Bluegill in 2023 was 2 per trap net. Thirty-one Bluegill ranging from nearly 3.5 inches to just under 10 inches were sampled with a mean length of 6 inches. The Lake Benton Sportsmen's Club also purchased 400 adult Bluegill in 2020. Angling for Bluegill will be difficult with a sparse population, however, if a fish is caught it will most likely be a larger individual.

NORTHERN PIKE

Northern Pike abundance in gill net samples has been at or above the long-term average of 1 per net over the past 3 surveys (since 2019). During 2023, the gill net catch rate was 1.2 per net and the trap net catch rate was 1 per trap net. Twenty-one Northern Pike were caught in gill nets and trap nets. Of the 21 Northern Pike caught only 4 were over the 24 inch minimum size limit in the southern zone of Minnesota. One Northern Pike was 36 inches showing some potential exists for large Northern Pike in Lake Benton. Northern Pike stocking in Lake Benton is rare due to inconsistent hatchery production with the last stocking occurring in 2006 (17,875 fingerling). The existing population is composed of younger fish that were either naturally spawned within the lake or from connected streams and wetlands upstream. Any improvements in Northern Pike abundance into the future may focus on spawning habitat identification and potential improvement. That all said, angling for Northern Pike specifically may be difficult but potential exists for abundance and size to improve, especially fish over 24 inches.

YELLOW PERCH

Yellow Perch are probably the second most popular species targeted by anglers while fishing Lake Benton. Yellow Perch abundance in Lake Benton has been up and down recently with 5.4 Yellow Perch per gill net in 2021 followed by 28.4 Yellow Perch per gill net in 2023. The long-term gill net catch average is 47 Yellow Perch per gill net, which has not been exceeded since 2019 (72.6 per gill net). While the 2023 gill net catch rate is less than the long-term average, it is still above the normal range for class 41 lakes (3.0 to 22.5 per gill net) indicating a potentially robust population. In addition, Yellow Perch size structure was good. Fish ranged in length from 6 to 11.5 inches with a mean length of 8 inches in the gill net sample. While the population level of Yellow Perch in Lake Benton can be up and down, size of Yellow Perch is typically above average for southwestern Minnesota populations. With 50% of fish over 8 inches, the Lake Benton Yellow Perch population is poised to provide an excellent angling opportunity.

OTHER SPECIES

Lake Benton is a simple fish community with few species sampled. The only other species sampled in 2023 include Black Bullhead, Common Carp, and White Sucker. Black Bullhead relative abundance is down from recent years to 14.8 per gill net and 18.5 per trap net in 2023. Common Carp relative abundance is also down from really high catch rates in 2019 (58.0 per gill net) and 2021 (69.8 per gill net) to 4.6 per gill net in 2023. Common Carp were infected with Carp Edema Virus (CEV) from August through October 2021 and is the most likely cause of the reduction in the number of Common Carp. White Sucker relative abundance is above long-term averages (8.56 per gill net, 1.85 per trap net) and also above the upper normal range for both gill nets and trap nets with 10.4 per gill net and 3.13 per trap net.

THE WAE POPULATION IS MADE UP OF AT LEAST 8 YEAR CLASSES, YOY INCLUDED. APPROXIMATELY 46% OF THE FISH SAMPLED WERE IN YEAR CLASSES ORIGINATING FROM NATURAL REPRODUCTION. AGE 3 WAE, REPRESENTING 36% OF FISH SAMPLED, WERE FROM NATURAL REPRODUCTION. THE TWO STRONGEST YEAR CLASSES, FROM A 1988 POPULATION ASSESSMENT, WERE FROM NATURAL REPRODUCTION. GILLNET CATCH INDICES FOR WAE WERE ALMOST TWICE THE UPPER END OF THE NORMAL RANGE FOR LAKE CLASS 40 INDICATING A HIGH POPULATION. GILLNET CATCH INDICES INCREASED FROM 14.8 FISH PER NET IN 1988 TO 19.2 FISH PER NET IN 1992. APPROXIMATELY 303 YOY WAE PER ACRE SEINED WERE CAPTURED FROM A 1992 NATURAL REPRODUCTION CHECK (106 FISH IN 5 SEINE HAULS). SHORELINE SEINING ALSO INDICATED NATURAL REPRODUCTION OF YEP AND BLC. THE WAE LENGTH FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION FROM GILL AND TRAPNETS RANGED FROM 9.0 TO 27.0 INCHES AGAIN INDICATING THE PRESENCE OF MULTIPLE YEAR CLASSES. THE PRESENT MANAGEMENT PLAN CALLS FOR STOCKING WAE FRY 2 OF 3 YEARS. SINCE SOME OF THE STRONGER YEAR CLASSES OCCURRED IN YEARS FRY WERE NOT STOCKED I WOULD RECOMMEND STOCKING FRY 1 OF 3 YEARS TO BETTER EVALUATE WAE NATURAL REPRODUCTION. IT MAY BE POSSIBLE TO MAINTAIN THE WAE POPULATION BY REDUCING STOCKING FREQUENCY. GILLNET CATCH INDICES FOR YEP FELL WITHIN THE NORMAL RANGE FOR THAT LAKE CLASS INDICATING A NORMAL POPULATION. THE POPULATION CONSISTS OF AT LEAST 7 YEAR CLASSES AND LENGTHS RANGED FROM 6.5 TO 14.0 INCHES. APPROXIMATELY 40% OF THE YEP CAPTURED IN THE SURVEY WERE 12.0 INCHES OR LONGER. TRAPNET CATCH INDICES FOR CARP, WTS, BLG AND BLC FELL WITHIN THE NORMAL RANGE FOR THAT LAKE CLASS INDICATING NORMAL POPULATIONS. THE LENGTH FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION FOR BLG RANGED FROM 3.5 TO 10.0 INCHES. THE BLG POPULATION WAS DOMINATED BY AGE 1 AND AGE 2 FISH (79% OF THE SAMPLE). THE LENGTH FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION FOR BLC RANGED FROM 5.0 TO 12.0 INCHES. THE POPULATION WAS DOMINATED BY AGE 4 FISH (71% OF THE POPULATION SAMPLED). TRAPNET CATCH INDICES FOR BLB WERE OVER 6 TIMES THE UPPER END OF THE NORMAL RANGE FOR THAT LAKE CLASS INDICATING A HIGH POPULATION. THREE OF THE 11 TRAPNETS CONTAINED 90% OF THE BLB SAMPLED. THE MEDIAN CATCH FOR BLB FROM TRAPNETS WAS 85.5 FISH PER NET. THE LENGTH FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION WAS BIMODAL. ONE GROUP RANGED FROM 4.0 TO 8.5 INCHES AND THE OTHER GROUP RANGED FROM 11.5 TO 14.0 INCHES.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre class 41 lake located in Lincoln County. Lake Benton is located nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border. The city of Lake Benton is located on the southwestern end of the lake at the intersection of US highways 14 and 75. The watershed of Lake Benton is primarily composed of agricultural development with roughly 90 percent of the watershed planted in primarily in row crops. Other uses of the Lake Benton watershed include forest/woodlands, grasslands, and municipal. The watershed-to-lake ratio is 9 to 1 indicating the influence of the land use practices in the lake. The immediate shoreline surrounding Lake Benton is composed mostly of grasslands (80%), and undeveloped forest or woodland (20%); however, some development is present in the Lake Benton city limits. More than 120 cabins or homes were present on Lake Benton in 2010. There were a total of six inlets to Lake Benton and the major outlet is Coon Creek.

Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 ft, a secchi depth of 1.8 feet and supported vegetation to a depth of 5 ft (based on the 2000 survey). Native aquatic plant species of submergent and emergent vegetation were rare in Lake Benton in 2000. Sago pondweed was the most commonly observed native aquatic vegetation with rare occurrences of common hornwort (coontail). Conversely, the exotic invasive curly leafed pondweed has been a common aquatic plant species in Lake Benton. The entire Lake Benton water basin had been treated with Fluridone from 2005 through 2008 and partial basin treatments were completed in 2009 in attempts to chemically control curly leafed pondweed. The Division of Ecological Resources continues to monitor the aquatic vegetation in Lake Benton annually through the treatment years. The shoal water substrate composition of Lake Benton was mostly gravel, sand, and rubble covered with detritus. The water level of Lake Benton was high during the summer of 2010 relative to historic observed water levels.

The fishery of Lake Benton is primarily managed for walleye and secondarily for northern pike, black crappie, bluegill, and yellow perch. A population assessment was conducted during the week of August 2, 2010 using gill nets and frame nets.

The walleye catch rate in Lake Benton was 45.33 fish/gill net, which is the highest observed catch rate since sampling began in 1956. The current catch rate is more than twice the long-term catch rate of 20.82 fish/net, and 3 times the higher normal range of 15.33 fish/net for this type of lake. The trap net catch rate (7.73 fish/net) is also the highest observed catch rate since sampling began in 1956; it is 4 times the higher normal range and twice the long-term average of 3.52 fish/net. Trap nets are usually poor indicators of walleye abundance, but high catch rates in trap nets along with high catch rates in gill nets indicates high population density. The average size of walleye caught in the gill nets was 11.2 inches with a range of 6.9 to 25.4 inches. Otolith ages revealed 8 year classes (1995, 1996, and 2004-2009) of walleye in Lake Benton with 47% of the fish from the 2009 (age 1) year class and 26% from the 2007 (age 3) year class. Four of the 8 year classes were naturally reproduced (1995, 1996, 2005, and 2008), although their abundance was low and comprised only 19% of the total population of walleye. It appears that natural reproduction is sporadic and inadequate to sustain a population of walleye in Lake Benton with the current demand and fishing pressure. While the population is dominated by younger walleye, growth of walleye in Lake Benton is good (14.4 inch average by age 3). Overall, the walleye population in Lake Benton appears to be at a high and in fair condition and growth rates are adequate to produce larger walleye. Over the next year, as the population matures, walleye larger than 15 inches will become more common. Walleye fishing during the next several years should be good, if not spectacular, in Lake Benton.

The northern pike catch rate in Lake Benton during 2010 was 1.3 fish/gill net which was within the interquartile range for lake class 41 (1.2 to 7.8) but almost twice the long-term average of 0.7 fish/gill net since 1956. Lake Benton has a historically low catch rate (0 to 2.1 fish/gill net) of northern pike and is most likely a result of degraded spawning habitat within the lake. To augment the population, northern pike fingerling were stocked in 2006 at a rate of 5 per acre. During the current survey, the length of northern pike ranged from 8.8 to 26.4 inches with a mean of 17.9 inches and all but one fish aged was the result natural reproduction. A naturally reproducing population of northern pike in Lake Benton could indicate an improvement in habitat for spawning. One of the naturally reproduced year classes (2009), with an average length of 16.4 inches, currently dominates the population of northern pike in Lake Benton. Over the next several years, as the population matures and with continued natural reproduction, larger northern pike (> 28 inches) will become more common. Fishing for northern pike in Lake Benton should be good over the next few years. Catch and release angling should be considered if larger pike are desired, otherwise northern pike are susceptible to high mortality due to overfishing as they are a voracious predator and strike at just about anything that fits into their mouth.

The current catch rate of black crappie in Lake Benton was 4.2 fish/trap net which is within the interquartile range for lake class 41 (1.0 to 12.3 fish/trap net). The long-term catch rate of black crappie in Lake Benton is 3.1 fish/trap net. During 2010 the black crappie ranged in length from 2.4 to 12.1 inches with a mean length of 8.1 inches. It appears that the black crappie population is doing well. Fishing for black crappie should be good and the action may be particularly hot in the spring months.

The bluegill catch rate during 2010 was 6.1 fish/trap net which was within the interquartile range for lake class 41 (1.1 to 14.9 fish/trap net) and equal to the long-term catch rate of 5.7 fish/trap net. Bluegill ranged in size from 3.5 to 10.2 inches with a mean of 6.8 inches. If the bluegill size structure remains similar to the current state and natural reproduction occurs in Lake Benton, then the bluegill population may regularly produce fish larger than 10 inches and a potential to produce trophy fish (>12 inches). Fishing for bluegill in Lake Benton is improving and the potential to catch a large bluegill is excellent.
The yellow perch catch rate was 12.7 fish/gill net in 2010 which was within the interquartile range for lake class 41 (3.0 to 22.5 fish/net) but only 25% of the long-term catch rate of 52.7 fish/gill net. The lengths of yellow perch ranged from 6.7 to 14.0 inches with a mean length of 9.6 inches. The growth of yellow perch in Lake Benton is excellent. Trophy (> 15 inches) yellow perch may be present in the population during the next year or two. Fishing for yellow perch in Lake Benton should be good and will supplement good fishing for walleye and bluegill.

The black bullhead catch rate in gill nets was 0.3 fish/net in 2010 which is less than the 25% quartile for lake class 41 (4.6 fish/net) and less than 1% of the long-term catch rate of 84.9 fish/net in Lake Benton. Only 17 black bullhead were sampled in 2010 using 6 gill nets and 15 trap nets. With the abundance of predator species such as walleye, northern pike, black crappie, and yellow perch and the small size structure of the black bullhead population it appears the black bullhead population will remain suppressed.

Other species sampled in 2010 were common carp, orangespotted sunfish, and white sucker.

Lake Benton appears to sustain a diverse fish community and should be a destination for walleye, northern pike, bluegill, and yellow perch anglers in southwestern Minnesota.

Prepared by Nate Hodgins

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre class 41 lake located in Lincoln County nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border and adjacent to the city of Lake Benton. The city of Lake Benton is located on the southwestern end of the lake at the intersection of US highways 14 and 75. The watershed of Lake Benton is primarily composed of agricultural development with roughly 90 percent of the watershed planted in row crops. Other uses of the Lake Benton watershed include woodlands, grasslands, and municipalities. The watershed-to-lake ratio is 9 to 1 indicating the influence of the land use practices in the lake. Any watershed ratio less than 30 to 1 is small and indicates an opportunity exists to improve water quality through natural resource oriented (particularly surface water flow) land management. In the case of Lake Benton, surrounding land practices that may improve water quality in the lake may include cover crops, buffer strips on waterways, and reduced or targeted fertilizer application. There are a total of six inlets to Lake Benton and the major outlet is Coon Creek.

Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 feet, a secchi depth of 2.3 feet, and supported vegetation to a depth of 8 feet (based on the 2012 point-intercept survey). Native aquatic plant species of submergent and emergent vegetation were rare in Lake Benton in 2012. Sago pondweed and common hornwort (coontail) were the only native species observed. Conversely, the exotic invasive curly leafed pondweed has been a common aquatic plant species in recent history on Lake Benton (2000-2006). The entire Lake Benton water basin had been treated with Fluridone from 2005 through 2008 and partial basin treatments were completed in 2009 in attempts to chemically control curly leafed pondweed. The Division of Ecological Resources continues to monitor the aquatic vegetation in Lake Benton annually through the treatment years. In 2012, curly leaf pondweed was found in very small quantities around the lake and was considered rare. The shoal water substrate composition of Lake Benton was mostly gravel, sand, and rubble covered with detritus. The water level of Lake Benton was at normal stage during the summer of 2013 relative to historic observed water levels.

The fishery of Lake Benton is primarily managed for walleye and secondarily for black crappie, bluegill, northern pike, and yellow perch. A population assessment was conducted the week of July 29th, 2013 with 4 gill nets and 15 trap nets to assess the managed fish species.


WALLEYE

The walleye catch rate in 2013 was the fourth highest catch rate since fish sampling began with 34.0 fish per gill net. The average size of walleye caught in the gill nets was 12.9 inches with fishing ranging in length from 7.9 to 21.7 inches. The current gill net catch rate is more than the long-term catch rate of 22.8 fish per net, and more than 2 times the upper expected catch rate value of 15.3 fish per net for Lake Benton. The trap net catch rate of 2.2 fish per net was also greater than the upper expected catch rate value of 1.7 fish per trap net for Lake Benton. However, the 2013 trap net catch rate was less than the long-term average of 2.9 fish per trap net. Trap nets are usually poor indicators of walleye abundance, but catch rates within or greater than the expected range along with high catch rates in gill nets indicates a high population density. A population abundance model developed by MN DNR researchers was used to estimate an approximate 2013 population abundance for Lake Benton based on the gill net catch of walleye. The population abundance model indicated that there may be anywhere between 85,318 and 356,684 (mean estimate = 219,128) walleye in Lake Benton with 24% of the walleye larger than the average size of 12.9 inches. Additionally, the population abundance model indicated that more than 50% of the walleye were between 8 and 10 inches. However, the size structure of walleye in the gill net and trap net catches indicated a more balanced size structure with 30% of the walleye being larger than 15 inches and 4% of the walleye being larger than 20 inches. Otoliths (ear bones) were used to get age information from the walleye in the gill net sample. Four different age groups of walleye were observed in Lake Benton; 28% were 1 year old, 53% were 2 years old, 17% were 4 years old, and 2% were 6 years old. Interestingly, the most abundant age group in the 2013 survey sample was the non-stocked 2-year-olds indicating substantial natural reproduction occurred in 2011. In the past, natural reproduction has been sporadic and inadequate to sustain a population of walleye in Lake Benton without supplemental walleye fry stocking. Natural reproduction remained sporadic in 2013 (only 1 of 4 age groups was naturally reproduced), but the 2013 survey showed that a very abundant naturally reproduced year class can become a major component of the walleye population and greatly contribute to the fishery. Past stocking of walleye fry in Lake Benton appears to be creating more opportunity for the walleye population to be able to successfully reproduce by stabilizing the population and adding potential spawning stock (fish old enough to reproduce) to the lake. While the population is currently dominated by younger walleye, growth of walleye in Lake Benton is good (13.8 inch average by age 3) which should allow the size structure of the population to remain in a balanced state. In addition, the overall health condition of walleye was good and indicates that the walleye are finding enough food to eat. Overall, the walleye population in Lake Benton appears to be at a fairly high level and in good health with a growth rate that may produce some larger walleye. Over the next several years, as the walleye mature, 15 inch walleye will become a more regular occurrence in angler's catches.


BLACK CRAPPIE

The current catch rate of black crappie in Lake Benton was 1.3 fish per trap net, which is within the expected catch rate range for Lake Benton (1.0 to 12.3 fish per trap net). The long-term catch rate of black crappie in Lake Benton is 3.0 fish per trap net. During the 1980s and early 1990s the black crappie catch rate was between 5.4 and 11.9 fish per trap net and the population appeared to be doing well, but from 1996 to 2009 the catch rate never exceeded 2.7 fish per net. More often than not the trap net catch rate was usually near 1 fish per net, indicating a population that may have been experiencing some stress. Then the trap net catch rate increased to 4.2 in 2010 and 3.3 in 2011, with several age groups present in each survey. The observation of a wide range of sizes in 2010 and 2011 was confusing due to low catch rates (less than 0.5 fish per net) from 2006 to 2009. It was speculated that the lake wide treatment of aquatic vegetation with Fluridone to remove curly-leaf pondweed was also removing native vegetation and placing stress on the black crappie population leading to a potential reduction in the population. However, it appeared the effect of the vegetation removal may have been limited to behavioral changes that influenced catch success in the DNR sampling gear rather than negative effects to the population abundance and condition. Currently, the black crappie population is comprised of 3 age groups with fish ranging from 7.6 to 11.6 inches (mean = 9.2 inches). The size structure is skewed toward bigger fish indicating a population of black crappie that is dominated by fish larger than 8 inches. The overall health of the black crappie was very good indicating the black crappie were finding enough prey items to eat. It appears that the black crappie population is doing well in 2013, but continued evaluation of the Lake Benton fish community every other year (2015, 2017, 2019, etc.) will be conducted to understand the full effects of the vegetation treatment with Fluridone on all fish species in Lake Benton.


BLUEGILL

The bluegill catch rate during 2013 was 0.9 fish per trap net which less than the lower expected catch rate value for Lake Benton (quartile range = 1.1 to 14.9 fish per trap net) and less than the long-term catch rate of 6.2 fish per trap net. Lake Benton has only had two years (1983 and 1996) with outstanding catch rates (50.4 fish per net and 17.3 fish per net) of bluegill. Since 2000, the catch rate has ranged from 0.1 to 6.1 fish per trap net and is usually near 1 fish per trap net. Since 2009, Becker's Resort on the south shore of Lake Benton has stocked adult bluegill with the last stocking in 2012. It appears the stocking is helping to sustain the bluegill fishery at a very low abundance, but reproduction is still limited. In 2013, the bluegill ranged in size from 7.6 to 8.6 inches with a mean of 8.1 inches. It is likely that all bluegill in the sample were from the same year class and potentially from the 2012 stocking of adult bluegill. The size structure of the bluegill in the sample favored larger fish with most fish being bigger than 8 inches. The overall condition of the bluegill was excellent indicating successful foraging and growth. If the future bluegill size structure remains similar to the current size structure and natural reproduction occurs in Lake Benton in the future, then the bluegill population may be able to sustain a population without stocking. Reproduction is sporadic and was last observed in 2011. In-lake habitat projects that include restoring patches of vegetation for bluegill spawning or adding artificial spawning structures may help to increase the population.


NORTHERN PIKE

The northern pike catch rate in Lake Benton during 2013 was 1.5 fish per gill net which was within the expected catch rate range for Lake Benton (1.2 to 7.8 fish per net) and almost twice the long-term average of 0.8 fish per gill net since 1956. Lake Benton has a historically low catch rate (0 to 2.2 fish per gill net) of northern pike, most likely a result of degraded spawning habitat within the lake. To augment the population, northern pike fingerling were stocked in 2006 at a rate of 5 per acre. During the current survey, the length of northern pike ranged from 9.1 to 31.0 inches with a mean of 20.6 inches in the gill net sample and a mean of 23.0 inches in the trap net sample. The size structure of northern pike in the sample was dominated by fish in the 21 to 28 inch range. The size structure of the northern pike has increased steadily since 2009. This may be due to a single age group of northern pike that is aging and growing with little or no naturally reproduced age groups following behind it. While the current catch rate is within the expected catch rate range, the DNR will continue to stock northern pike fingerling in the lake as they become available during spring northern pike production to sustain the population. Several poor years of northern pike fingerling production due to drought and unusual warm or cold weather cycles during spring of 2012 and 2013 have made stocking fingerling nearly impossible in the Windom Fisheries Management Area. Additionally, in-lake habitat improvements to increase spawning potential of northern pike should be considered. An example of an improvement in habitat could be as simple as less frequent herbicide use to leave some aquatic vegetation patches, especially in bays. Over the next several years, as the population matures and with some natural reproduction or stocking, larger northern pike may become more common.


YELLOW PERCH

The 2013 yellow perch catch rate was 6.8 fish per gill net, within the expected catch rate range for Lake Benton (3.0 to 22.5 fish per net) but less than the long-term catch rate of 48.8 fish per gill net. Historically, the yellow perch catch has been within or above the expected catch rate range during every survey except 2005. The yellow perch population abundance has been sporadic since sampling began on Lake Benton. In the same way, the size structure of the yellow perch population has been sporadic with the starkest changes occurring since 2003. The sporadic nature of the yellow perch population is most likely the result of a boom and bust style of reproduction where there are very successful spawning years followed by several years of little to no spawning success. In 2013, the lengths of yellow perch in the sample ranged from 7.1 to 11.3 inches with a mean length of 9.4 inches in the gill nets and 9.3 inches in the trap nets. Most yellow perch in the sample were greater than 8 inches. The overall health of the population was excellent, indicating the fish are finding enough prey to eat. The yellow perch population appears to be entering a phase where large fish dominate the system because reproduction has been lacking since 2011, or predation has cropped off the younger and smaller fish in recent years. Success of walleye and northern pike populations are directly tied to abundance of yellow perch in many lakes and Lake Benton is no different. If successful reproduction of yellow perch is not realized seen by the 2015 or 2017 lake survey, walleye and northern pike population abundances could be negatively impacted. One thing that will dull the effect of a reduction in yellow perch is the presence of many black bullhead in 2013 that will provide forage for walleye and northern pike.


BLACK BULLHEAD

The black bullhead catch rate in gill nets was 125.0 fish per net in 2013 which was greater than the upper expected catch rate value of 83.0 fish per gill net for Lake Benton (interquartile range = 4.6 to 83.0 fish per gill net) and 1.5 times the long-term catch rate of 82.9 fish per gill net. The 2013 catch rate is up from 17.0 bullhead per gill net in 2011 and 0.33 per gill net in 2010 and the highest catch rate since 356.2 fish per gill net in 2006. From 2007 to 2011 the black bullhead abundance was dramatically below levels observed from 2000 to 2006 (83.2 to 356.2 fish per gill net). It was speculated that poor reproduction and increased mortality through predation as well as angling were most likely responsible for the decline from 2007-2011. Bullhead observed in the 2013 sample ranged in length from 4.8 to 14.1 inches with a mean length of 8.1 inches in the gill nets and 8.3 inches in the trap nets. Extremely successful reproduction in 2011 and 2012 most likely led to the increase in the bullhead abundance observed in 2013. With the decrease in abundance of yellow perch and the increase in abundance of black bullhead, it is possible the black bullhead population will become a major component of the walleye forage base in 2013 and possibly into 2014.


OTHER SPECIES

Other species sampled in 2013 were common carp, green sunfish, and white sucker. The common carp catch rate in gill nets (0.5 fish per net) was nearly equal to the lower expected catch rate value for Lake Benton (0.52 to 9.13 fish per net) and one of the lowest catch rates of common carp observed since 2006. The green sunfish gill net (0.25 fish per net) and trap net (0.13 fish per net) catch rates were within the expected catch rate ranges for each net type (gillnet = 0.17 to 2.75 fish per net; trap net = 0.13 to 0.66 fish per net). The white sucker catch rate of 6.0 fish per gill net exceeded the expected catch rate range for Lake Benton (0.8 to 5.9 fish per gill net) for the 3 straight survey in a row (2010, 2011, and 2013); white sucker continue to be the most abundant large forage fish for the larger predators (large walleye and northern pike) in Lake Benton.

While Lake Benton supports a limited diversity of fish, it should be a destination for walleye anglers in southwestern Minnesota. When the bite is on, anglers could have the opportunity to catch their limit of walleye in the 13 to 15 inch range with some fish larger than 20 inches as a bonus. To have a chance to catch the big one you need to wet a line, get out there and give it a try!

Prepared by Nate Hodgins

Lake Benton which covers 2857 acres is one of the larger lakes in the Windom Area. The lake has a shoreline length of 18.1 miles and a maximum depth of 9 feet. The surrounding watershed is dominated by agricultural lands and the immediate shoreline is fringed with hardwoods. More than one hundred homes and cottages which are predominantly located along the south shore border Lake Benton. Gravel, sand, and rubble substrates dominate shoalwater areas. According to a survey conducted in 1992, submergent and emergent vegetation are considered abundant. Lake Benton is managed primarily for walleye and secondarily for northern pike and black crappie. A dense and expanding stand of curled leaf pond weed covers nearly half the lake surface area from spring to midsummer. The stand which is located on the west side of the lake makes boating and fishing difficult in this area. Although the abundance of curled leaf pond weed may be detrimental to recreational boating activities in Lake Benton, fish species may ultimately benefit. Aquatic vegetation provide fish additional spawning habitat, cover, and related food resources. In addition, aquatic vegetation improves water quality by using nutrients which may otherwise be used by undesirable blue-green algae. The vegetation also reduces the amount of suspended solids in a lake by reducing the effect of wave action which stirs up bottom sediments. Walleye numbers are considered high compared to similar lakes in our area. Walleye collected in gillnets ranged in length from 9 to almost 28 inches with an average length of approximately 17 ? inches. The population is comprised mainly of large fish with many reaching preferred lengths (greater than 20 inches). The walleye population is supported through a combination of stocking and natural reproduction. Walleye fry were stocked in 1988, 1990, 1991, 1993, and 1994.Northern Pike numbers are considered normal. Pike sampled in gillnets ranged in length from 15 to nearly 31 inches with an average length of approximately 24 ? inches. The northern pike population is healthy and self-supporting. Black crappie numbers are considered low compared to similar lakes in our area. Black crappie sampled in trapnets ranged in length from 5 to almost 9 inches with an average length of approximately 7 inches. Although the current numbers are low, black crappie populations characteristically cycle in abundance, and thus black crappie numbers in Lake Benton should rebound to normal levels in subsequent years. The black crappie population is healthy and supported through natural reproduction.Yellow perch numbers increased since the 1992 survey and are currently considered high compared to other lakes in our area. Yellow perch collected in gillnets ranged in length from 5 to more than 11 ? inches with an average length of approximately 7 inches. Although the population is comprised mainly of small fish, with adequate growth, good numbers of fish should reach quality lengths (greater than 8 inches) in subsequent years. The yellow perch population is also self-supporting. Bluegill numbers have also increased since the 1992 survey and are currently considered high. Bluegill sampled in trapnets ranged in length from 3 to almost 10 inches with an average length of approximately 4 inches. Similar to the yellow perch population, the current bluegill population is dominated by small fish but should also provide good numbers of quality size fish in subsequent years. The bluegill population is healthy and self-supporting.Black bullhead numbers are considered normal. Bullhead sampled in trapnets ranged in length from 4 to more than 14 inches with an average length of approximately 8 inches.Other species observed during the 1996 survey include largemouth bass, green sunfish, carp, white sucker, and johnny darter.A creel survey was also conducted on Lake Benton during the 1996 walleye fishing season. Total estimated angling pressure from May 11, 1996 through February 16, 1997 (excluding November) was 38,275 angler hours (15,940 angler trips), or 13.4 angler hours per acre. Ninety-one percent of the pressure occurred during the summer and 9.0% during the winter. Anglers from 14 states fished the lake with Minnesota residents accounting for 79% of the angler trips. Ten species of fish were caught, of which yellow perch, black bullhead, walleye, and largemouth bass were caught most frequently. Total estimated harvest of all species was 18,816 fish, or 6.59 fish per acre. Total yield was 7,394 pounds, or 2.59 pounds per acre. A total of 3,689 walleye were caught, of which 25% were harvested. The majority of harvested walleye were from the 1993 and 1994 year classes. To promote and maintain a healthy fish population, pollution and other inputs need to be controlled. Fish habitat is directly affected by water quality. Nutrient, sediment and other waste inputs can drastically alter the chemical and physical components of a Lake. It is paramount to maintain if not improve the current water quality of Lake Benton through watershed management to preserve this fishery for future generations to enjoy.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre class 41 lake located in western Lincoln County. Lake Benton is located nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border. The city of Lake Benton is located on the southwestern end of the lake at the intersection of US highways 14 and 75.

The watershed of Lake Benton is primarily composed of agricultural development with roughly 90 percent of the watershed planted in primarily in row crops. Other uses of the Lake Benton watershed include forest/woodlands, grasslands, and municipal. The immediate shoreline surrounding Lake Benton is composed mostly of undeveloped forest or woodland (80%), and grassland (20%); however, some development is present in the Lake Benton city limits. Residentially, 128 cabins or homes were present on Lake Benton in 2006. Recreational use is apparently important on Lake Benton and during this survey a total of 127 boats were observed on or around the perimeter of the lake basin. There were a total of six inlets to Lake Benton, but only a single inlet with a recordable flow (Norwegian Creek) at the time of this survey. Outflows from Lake Benton include Coon Creek, which was flowing at the time of this survey.

Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 ft, a secchi depth of 2 feet and supported vegetation to a depth of 5 ft (based on the 2000 survey). Native aquatic plant species of submergent and emergent vegetation were rare in Lake Benton in 2000. Sago pondweed was the most commonly observed native aquatic vegetation. Conversely, the exotic invasive curly leafed pondweed has been a common aquatic plant species in Lake Benton. Subsequently, the entire Lake Benton water basin had been treated with Fluridone from 2005 through 2008 and partial basin treatments were completed in 2009 in attempts to chemically control curly leafed pondweed. The Division of Ecological Resources continues to monitor the aquatic vegetation in Lake Benton annually through the treatment years. The shoal water substrate composition of Lake Benton was mostly gravel, sand, and rubble covered with detritus. The water level of Lake Benton was normal during the summer of 2006 relative to historic observed water levels.
The fishery of Lake Benton is primarily managed for walleye and secondarily for black crappie, bluegill, northern pike and yellow perch. A population assessment was conducted during the week of July 30, 2009 using gill nets and frame nets.

During 2009, total lengths of walleye captured in gill nets ranged from 10 to 22 inches with an average length of just over 14 inches. The walleye size structure was slightly smaller than a typical balanced population, but still respectable. Recent large years classes in 2008 and 2007 make up the majority of the population and is the reason the sizes are shifted a bit to the smaller side. The condition of walleye in Lake Benton was within the objective range indicating appropriate food availability. From 2000 to 2007 the growth of walleye had was below desired. For example, walleye that were 16.1 inches in length at age-3 in 2000 were only 11.6 inches in length at age-3 in 2007, indicating a decline in growth rate. However, currently walleye obtain 15 inches by about the third year of growth, which is considered very good. Ultimately, the growth of walleye in Lake Benton seems to have increased since 2007.

Stocking of walleye in Lake Benton has been through fry stocking on an every-other-year basis. Stocked walleye have contributed to the walleye population based on ages of walleye captured during the 2009 survey, except the 2002 stocking, which was not observed. Natural reproduction may be present in Lake Benton as evidenced by the age of walleye present from non-stocked years. A modest year-class of walleye was apparently naturally reproduced in 2008, which was not a stocked year. Overall, the current relative abundance, size structure, and growth of walleye in Lake Benton indicate that the population is healthy, well balanced but slightly smaller than expected, and achieving appropriate growth.

Lake Benton supports a population of northern pike that is usually low in numbers.
