Catch rates of northern pike in gill nets have ranged from 0 to 2 fish/net with an average of just under one fish/net since 1951. The 2009 survey indicated that northern pike were slightly above the historic average for numbers of fish, but below the objective range (1.2  7.8 fish/net) for lake class 41. Northern pike captured in gill nets ranged in length from about 17 to 22 inches with an average of just over 19 inches, so the pike in Lake Benton are a bit on the small end. Northern pike were last stocked into Lake Benton in 2006 when 17,875 fingerlings raised at Shetek rearing ponds were stocked into Lake Benton. So, the majority of the pike in the lake are about 4 years old. The condition of northern pike in Lake Benton was good and sufficient food is available to the pike. Overall, the size structure was slightly lower than desired, but the condition of northern pike in Lake Benton at the time of this survey was acceptable.

Historically, yellow perch abundances have been maintained well above similar lakes. For example, yellow perch gill net catches ranged from about 7 to 340 fish/net from 1951 through 2000. Beginning in 2003 the number of perch in the gill nets began to decline and has since been below 7 fish/net. In fact, the yellow perch catches of 2 to 5 fish fish/net observed from 2005 through 2009 are the lowest abundances ever recorded in Lake Benton and have occurred on consecutive years. During 2009, yellow perch captured in gill nets ranged in length from almost 10 inches up to over 12 inches. The average length of perch during 2009 was about 10.5 inches. The length distribution of yellow perch in Lake Benton during 2009 indicated that the population is comprised of mostly larger fish, indicating an unbalanced population. This indicates that natural reproduction and recruitment of young to the adult population has been limited in recent years. Yellow perch populations naturally fluctuate over time usually peaking when predator abundance (such as walleye or pike) is lowest; however, the yellow perch population is currently in the extreme low end or below the objective range for abundance and the population is comprised of mostly larger fish. One important note is that yellow perch rely on submerged vegetation for spawning habitat and the removal of vegetation through the recent treatments of curlyleaf pondweed has most likely negatively impacted perch reproduction. In fact, the mean length of yellow perch has essentially increased each year since 2003, which indicates that the population has shifted to fewer numbers and larger individuals. Although the size and condition of the yellow perch in Lake Benton is good for anglers, the low numbers of fish probably doesnt provide a fast bite.

Generally, the black crappie and bluegill numbers in Lake Benton have been maintained within expected ranges. However, the numbers based on trap nets for both black crappie and bluegill was 0.3 fish/net in 2009, which fell below objective ranges of 1  12 and 1  15, respectively. Few black crappie or bluegills were captured making estimation of mean length and population size distribution difficult. However, based on the few fish that were caught, the black crappie are about 5 inches in length and the bluegill are near 4 inches in length. Overall, the black crappie and bluegill populations in Lake Benton are comprised of fish that are in good overall condition, but are extremely low in abundance and relatively small. The loss of aquatic vegetation through treatments of curly leaf pondweed has most likely negatively affected the panfish in the lake since they rely on that vegetation for reproduction, food, and cover.

Black bullhead numbers in Lake Benton have ranged from about 3 to 440 fish/net in the 50 years from 1956 through 2006. However, beginning in 2003 the abundance of black bullhead increased to well above the historic mean due to the establishment of a very large 2002 year class (fish hatched in 2002). Subsequently, there has been limited recruitment of black bullhead since 2002 and as that year class has been eroded through natural mortality and hooking mortality the overall population numbers have declined each year. In fact, during 2009 the black bullhead numbers were less than one fishnet and the lowest numbers of black bullhead observed in Lake Benton since 1951. Ultimately, the cause for the decrease in abundance of black bullhead since 2003 is not well understood but the lake seems likely to demonstrate another very large year-class of bullhead in the next couple years given the history of occasional large year classes in Lake Benton.

The catch of common carp in trap nets has remained steady in Lake Benton with the numbers in the lower range for similar lakes. During 2009, the frame net catch was less than one fish/net and below the historic average (3 fish/net). Maintaining low common carp abundance is important to aid in re-establishing native aquatic vegetation in the lake following the treatments to control curly leafed pondweed. The suppression of common carp in Lake Benton has been successful due-in-part to the high walleye numbers that has been historically maintained.

Other species: Other species captured during the 2009 population assessment included white sucker.

-Prepared by Craig Soupir, NR Fisheries Specialist

THE WALLEYE GILLNET CATCH INDEX IS 4.1 TIMES THE STATE MEDIAN AND 2.8 TIMES THE LOCAL MEDIAN. THE LENGTH FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION OF WALLEYES SAMPLED IN THE GILL NET IS RELATIVELY WIDE WITH A RANGE OF 8.0 TO 26.9 INCHES WITH A MODE AT 12 INCHES AND ANOTHER AT 17 INCHES. THE AVERAGE WEIGHT OF THE WALLEYES CAPTURED IN THE GILLNET WAS 1.8 LBS. THE AGE CLASSES ARE BROADLY DISTRIBUTED FROM AGE 1 TO AGE 9 AND WITH REPRESENTATION OF ALL AGES IN BE- TWEEN. WALLEYE FRY WERE STOCKED IN 1983, 1985 AND 1988. THE 1986 AND 1987 YEAR CLASSES PROBABLY ORIGINATED FROM NATURAL REPRODUCTION. SHORELINE SEINING ON AUGUST 17, 1988 PRODUCED 15.7 YOY WALLEYE PER ACRE SEINED. YELLOW PERCH WERE CAPTURED BY GILL NETS IN NUMBERS SIMILAR TO THE LOCAL MEDIAN. THE LENGTH FREQUENCY OF THE YELLOW PERCH SAMPLED IS RELATIVELY WIDE WITH A RANGE FROM 5.5 TO 13.9 INCHES AND A MODE OF 7.0 INCHES. THE AVERAGE WEIGHT WAS 0.33 LBS. ONLY TWO YELLOW PERCH WERE CAPTURED IN 1.15 ACRES OF SHORELINE SEINED. THE BLACK BULLHEAD POPULATION APPEARS TO BE VERY SMALL AND IS DOMINATED BY A FEW LARGE FISH. THE TRAPNET CATCH OF 4.1 FISH PER LIFT IS WELL BELOW THE LOCAL MEDIAN OF 75.1 FISH PER LIFT. THE AVER- AGE WEIGHT OF THE BULLHEADS IN THE TRAP NETS WAS 1.5 LBS. SHORELINE SEINING IN 1988 PRODUCED 568 YOY BLACK BULLHEADS PER ACRE SEINED. THE GILLNET CATCH INDEX FOR NORTHERN PIKE WAS 1.2 FISH PER LIFT WHICH IS SIMILAR TO THE LOCAL MEDIAN OF 1.5 FISH PER LIFT. ALL OF THE FISH SAMPLED WERE AGE 1 OR AGE 2 FISH AND AVERAGED 1.8 LBS. THE TRAPNET INDEX FOR BLUEGILL IS 11% BELOW THE LOCAL MEDIAN. THE TRAPNET CATCH INDEX FOR BLACK CRAPPIE IS SLIGHTLY BELOW THE LOCAL MEDIAN. THE MAJORITY OF FISH OF BOTH SPECIES WERE AGE 1 AND 2. SHORELINE SEINING PRODUCED 91.3 YOY BLUEGILLS PER ACRE SEINED AND 31.3 YOY BLACK CRAPPIE PER ACRE SEINED. THE TRAPNET CATCH INDEX FOR CARP IS 58% BELOW THE LOCAL MEDIAN, WITH MOST FISH MEASURING 16 WEIGHING APPROXIMATELY 2.5 LBS. LARGEMOUTH BASS WERE NOT FOUND DURING TEST NETTING OR DURING SHORELINE SEINING. THEY HAVE BEEN STOCKED THREE TIMES IN RECENT YEARS, 1982 - 5,134 FGLS,; 1984 - 11,120 FGLS. AND 1986 - 14,904 FGLS. DURING THE LAST FEW YEARS, ONLY A FEW FISH HAVE BEEN CAUGHT. THE OWNER OF THE LAKE BENTON BAIT SHOP REPORTS THAT HE KNOWS OF TWO BASS THAT WERE CAUGHT DURING 1988.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre, class 41 lake that is adjacent to the City of Lake Benton in Lincoln County. Lake Benton is managed primarily for Walleye and secondarily for Yellow Perch, Northern Pike, Black Crappie, and Bluegill. Since 2006, natural reproduction of Walleye has been documented in each non-stocked year (2008, 2011, and 2014). Due to the documentation of natural reproduction, Lake Benton was stocked with Lower Mississippi Strain (LMS) of Walleye in 2018. The LMS strain is the same strain that is found in Lake Sarah, which has one of the only Walleye populations in the Windom fisheries management area that is sustained through natural reproduction. A recent genetics study found that Lake Sarah's Walleye are unique to the Cannon River in east-central Minnesota, which was used as an egg source decades ago. Further genetic testing has shown that this strain of Walleye has persisted in Lake Benton despite extensive stocking of other strains of Walleye. A Walleye fry stocking evaluation using night electrofishing was conducted on October 23, 2018 to determine if the 2018 fry stocking was successful.

Young-of-the-year (YOY) Walleye were captured at a rate of 68.0 per hour, which indicates that the fry stocking was successful. Genetic analysis revealed 95% of the YOY Walleye were from stocking. Walleye fingerlings ranged in length from 8.8 to 11.4 inches and averaged 10.6 inches. This year class should recruit to the fishery because of the large size of the fingerlings.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre lake located in western Lincoln County. The lake is located nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border and is partially in the city of Lake Benton. Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9.0 feet, has 18 miles of shoreline and is a class 41 lake. Benton is managed primarily for walleye while yellow perch, black crappie, and northern pike are managed secondarily. Native aquatic plant species of submergent and emergent vegetation were rare in 2000 with sago pondweed the most commonly observed native aquatic plant. Conversely, the exotic invasive curly leaf pondweed has become extremely abundant in Lake Benton. As a result, the entire Lake Benton basin was treated with Fluridone in 2005, 2006, and 2007. Additional treatments are scheduled through 2009 to attempt to chemically control the exotic species. Native vegetation was harvested from Shaokotan in 2007 and planted in Lake Benton. Enclosures were put around the plant to protect them from being rooted up in an attempt to restore native vegetation. Annual assessments are planned on Lake Benton to determine what impacts, if any, the chemical treatments may have on fish and vegetation populations. Lake Benton has a very good walleye population. The walleye gill net catch rate was 16.8 per net in 2007 compared to 9.8 per net in 2006, 4.5 per net in 2005, and 13.3 per net in 2003. The higher catch rates in 2007 are due primarily to a strong year class of age-1 fish which means good fishing opportunities in the future. Lengths of walleye caught in gill nets ranged from 7.4 to 25.2 inches and averaged 11.8 inches. Eleven age classes were observed during the assessment from age-1 fish to age-14 fish. There appeared to be good natural reproduction in 1995, 1996, and 1999. Some natural reproduction also occurred in 2001 and 2003. The number of yellow perch in Lake Benton is similar to lakes with physical characteristics like Lake Benton. The yellow perch catch rate was 5.0 per net in 2007 compared to 2.7 per net in 2006, 1.8 per net in 2005, and 6.7 per net in 2003. Lengths of yellow perch caught in gill nets ranged from 6.2 to 11.4 inches and averaged 8.6 inches. Black crappie numbers are low in Lake Benton. The black crappie catch rate was 0.6 per net in 2007 compared to 0.5 per net in 2006 and 1.9 per net in 2005. Lengths of black crappie caught in trap nets ranged from 4.8 to 9.3 inches and averaged 6.1 inches. No northern pike were sampled during the 2007 assessment. Benton has a history of producing some large northern pike so 18,000 northern pike fingerlings were stocked in 2006 in an attempt to increase the northern pike population. Black bullhead numbers appear to be down to a more manageable level in Lake Benton. The black bullhead trap net catch rate was 14.7 per net in 2007 compared to 176.9 in 2006 and 297.0 in 2005. Lengths of black bullhead caught in trap nets ranged from 8.5 to 11.7 inches and averaged10.3 inches. Other species sampled during the assessment included bluegill, green sunfish, largemouth bass, common carp, and white sucker. To maintain a healthy fishery in Lake Benton, we need to promote Best Management Practices (BMPs) within the watershed to help reduce nutrients entering the lake. High nutrients and sediments in a lake can cause algae blooms and reduce water clarity.

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre class 41 lake located in Lincoln County. Lake Benton is located nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border. The city of Lake Benton is located on the southwestern end of the lake at the intersection of US highways 14 and 75. The watershed of Lake Benton is primarily composed of agricultural development with roughly 90 percent of the watershed planted primarily in row crops. Other uses of the Lake Benton watershed include forest per woodlands, grasslands, and municipal. The watershed-to-lake ratio is 9 to 1 indicating the influence of the land use practices in the lake. The immediate shoreline surrounding Lake Benton is composed mostly of grasslands (80%), and undeveloped forest or woodland (20%); however, some development is present in the Lake Benton city limits. More than 120 cabins or homes were present on Lake Benton in 2011. There were a total of six inlets to Lake Benton and the major outlet is Coon Creek.


Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 ft, a secchi depth of 1.8 feet and supported vegetation to a depth of 5 ft (based on the 2000 survey). Native aquatic plant species of submergent and emergent vegetation were rare in Lake Benton in 2000. Sago pondweed was the most commonly observed native aquatic vegetation with rare occurrences of common hornwort (coontail). Conversely, the exotic invasive curly leafed pondweed has been a common aquatic plant species in Lake Benton. The entire Lake Benton water basin had been treated with Fluridone from 2005 through 2008 and partial basin treatments were completed in 2009 in attempts to chemically control curly leafed pondweed. The Division of Ecological Resources continues to monitor the aquatic vegetation in Lake Benton annually through the treatment years. The shoal water substrate composition of Lake Benton was mostly gravel, sand, and rubble covered with detritus. The water level of Lake Benton was at normal stage during the summer of 2011 relative to historic observed water levels.


The fishery of Lake Benton is primarily managed for walleye and secondarily for northern pike, black crappie, bluegill, and yellow perch. A population assessment was conducted the week of August 1st, 2011 with 4 gill nets, 15 trap nets, along with nearshore index of biotic integrity (IBI) sampling (seining and backpack electrofishing for whole community assessment).


The walleye catch rate in Lake Benton was 45.3 fish per gill net, which is the second greatest catch rate since fish sampling began in 1956. The current catch rate is almost twice the long-term catch rate of 23.9 fish per net, and 3 times the 75% quartile of 15.33 fish per net for lake class 41. The average size of walleye caught in the gill nets was 14.9 inches with a range of 10.9 to 22.1 inches. Otolith (ear bone) ages revealed 6 year classes (2002, 2004, and 2006-2009) of walleye in Lake Benton with 47% of the fish from the 2009 (age 2) year class, 21% from the 2008 (age 3) year class, and 19% from the 2007 (age 4) year class. Age and growth data indicated 1 (2008) of the 8 year classes was naturally reproduced. It appears that natural reproduction is sporadic and inadequate to sustain a population of walleye in Lake Benton with the current demand and fishing pressure, therefore walleye fry stocking occurs 2 out of every 3 years. The proportion of young (less than 3 years) walleye in Lake Benton indicates a population of walleye that is dominated by younger and smaller fish. While the population is dominated by younger walleye, growth of walleye in Lake Benton is good (15.1 inch average by age 3), which allows the size structure of the population to be in a balanced state. The overall condition of walleye was fair and indicates that the walleye may in fact be at a very high abundance and competing with each other for limited prey items. Over the next several years, as the population matures, quality size walleye (greater than 15 inches) may become more common.


The northern pike catch rate in Lake Benton during 2011 was 1.3 fish per gill net which was within the normal range for lake class 41 (1.2 to 7.8) and almost twice the long-term average of 0.8 fish per gill net since 1996. Lake Benton has a historically low catch rate (0 to 2.2 fish per gill net) of northern pike that is most likely a result of degraded spawning habitat within the lake. To augment the population, northern pike fingerling were stocked in 2006 at a rate of 5 per acre. During the current survey, the length of northern pike ranged from 14.0 to 21.8 inches with a mean of 20.9 inches. The size of fish caught in the sample indicated a population of northern pike that is dominated by 21 to 28 inch fish. A naturally reproduced year class in 2009, with an average length between 20 and 24 inches currently dominates the population of northern pike in Lake Benton. Over the next several years, as the population matures and with continued natural reproduction, larger northern pike (greater than 28 inches) may become more common.


The current catch rate of black crappie in Lake Benton was 3.3 fish per trap net which is within the normal range for lake class 41 (1.0 to 12.3 fish per trap net). The long-term catch rate of black crappie in Lake Benton is 1.8 fish per trap net. During the 1980s and early 1990s the black crappie catch rate was between 5.4 and 11.9 fish per trap net and the population appeared to be doing well, but from 1996 to 2009 the catch rate never exceeded 2.7 fish per net. During 2011 the black crappie ranged in length from 6.1 to 11.3 inches with a mean length of 7.7 inches. Some reproduction was found with 18 age-0 black crappie caught in nearshore IBI sampling. The size of fish caught indicated a population of black crappie with a balanced size structure. The condition of the black crappie was excellent and showed that the fish are foraging successfully. The presence of a wide range of sizes in 2011 is confusing due to low catch rates (less than 0.5 fish per net) from 2006 to 2009. It was speculated that the lake wide treatment of aquatic vegetation with Fluridone to remove curly pondweed was also removing native vegetation and placing stress on the black crappie population. It is possible the affect of the vegetation removal may have been limited to behavioral changes that may have influenced reproduction and catch success rather than affecting the population condition. It appears that the black crappie population is doing well, but continued evaluation of the Lake Benton fish community should be conducted to understand the full effects of the vegetation treatment on natural reproduction.


The bluegill catch rate during 2011 was 1.6 fish per trap net which was within the normal range for lake class 41 (1.1 to 14.9 fish per trap net) and equal to the long-term catch rate of 1.5 fish per trap net. Lake Benton has only had one year (1983) with an outstanding catch rate (50.4 fish per net) of bluegill. Since 1983, the catch rate has ranged from 0.1 to 5.3 fish per trap net and is usually near 1 fish per trap net. In 2009, Becker's Resort on Lake Benton obtained a permit to stock bluegill. In the fall of 2009, around 1000 adult bluegill (at a rate of 20 per pound) were stocked. In 2010, the catch rate peaked to 6.1 fish per trap net. In 2011, the bluegill ranged in size from 3.4 to 9.5 inches with a mean of 6.7 inches. The size of fish in the sample indicated a population of bluegill that is starting to be dominated by larger (> 8 inches) fish. The condition of the bluegill was spectacular, indicating a population of bluegill that is successfully foraging and growing well. If the bluegill size structure remains similar to the current state and natural reproduction occurs in Lake Benton, then the bluegill population may regularly produce very large (greater than 10 inches) and plump individuals with the potential to produce trophy fish (greater than 12 inches). Reproduction was present in 2011 with 26 age-0 bluegill caught in the nearshore IBI sampling. It should be noted that bluegill reproduction is often found when aquatic vegetation is in adequate supply.


The yellow perch catch rate was 43.8 fish per gill net in 2011 which exceeded the normal range for lake class 41 (3.0 to 22.5 fish per net) and the long-term catch rate of 30.2 fish per gill net. The lengths of yellow perch ranged from 5.3 to 14.2 inches with a mean length of 7.7 inches. The sample of fish in 2011 indicated the population of yellow perch was dominated by small (less than 8 inches) fish. The condition of the population was excellent indicating the fish are foraging successfully. Trophy (greater than 15 inches) yellow perch may be present in the lake but were not sampled in the gill net catch during 2011. The yellow perch population appears stable. Additionally, nearshore IBI sampling showed adequate natural reproduction with 119 age-0 yellow perch (2.5 to 3.7 inches) caught in 10 seine hauls.


The black bullhead catch rate in gill nets was 17.0 fish per gill net in 2011 which was within the normal range for lake class 41 (4.6 to 83.0 fish per gill net) but only 15% of the long-term catch rate of 108.6 fish per gill net in Lake Benton. Only 124 black bullheads were sampled in 2011 using 4 gill nets and 15 trap nets. Since 2006, black bullhead abundance has dropped dramatically from catch rates in the hundreds per gill net. Poor reproduction and increased mortality through predation and fishing are possible sources for the decline. With the abundance of predator species such as walleye, northern pike, black crappie, and yellow perch it appears the black bullhead population may remain lower in abundance.


Other species sampled in 2011 were common carp, orangespotted sunfish, green sunfish and white sucker. The common carp catch rate in gill nets (2.3 fish per net) is within the normal range for lake class 41 (0.5 to 9.1 fish per net). Orangespotted sunfish are not effectively sampled with standard survey trap nets due to the sunfish's small size; one individual was caught in a seine haul. Green sunfish are also ineffectively sampled with standard survey nets, the 2 fish were caught with backpack electrofishing. The white sucker catch rate (8.0 fish per gill net) was the second highest observed exceeding the normal range for lake class 41 (0.8 to 5.9 fish per gill net); white sucker appear to be the most abundant forage base for the larger predators (large walleye and northern pike) in Lake Benton.


Lake Benton appears to sustain a limited diversity of fish and should be a destination for walleye, northern pike, bluegill, and yellow perch anglers in southwestern Minnesota.


Prepared by Nate Hodgins

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre lake that is classified as a DNR class 41 lake located in Lincoln County nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border and adjacent to the city of Lake Benton at County Highway 14 and US Highway 75. A class 41 lake is shallow and relatively large with good areas of sand and gravel lake bottom. The surrounding land area that drains to Lake Benton is row-crop dominated with roughly 90 percent of the watershed planted in corn and soybeans. Part of the 10% that is not in row crops is the immediate shoreline surrounding Lake Benton. The immediate shoreline land area is composed mostly of grasslands (80%), and undeveloped forest or woodland (20%); however, some urban development is present in the Lake Benton city limits. The watershed-to-lake ratio is 9 upland acres for every 1 lake acre, which indicates a fairly small contributing watershed in relation to the lake size. In general, the smaller the ratio the more realistic it is to positively influence the water quality of the lake by improving land-use practices in the upland areas of the watershed. In the case of Lake Benton, surrounding land practices that may improve water quality in the lake may include no till farming, cover crops planted in September, increased buffer strips on waterways, and reduced or targeted fertilizer application. More than 120 cabins or homes were present on Lake Benton in 2013 and no additional changes were noted in 2015. There are a total of six inlets and one major outlet (Coon Creek).

Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 feet, average summer water clarity of 2.5 feet, and at times supports vegetation to 8 feet deep. Recently underwater and above water vegetation in the lake was sparse and was composed of native species with no obvious presence of curly leaf pondweed at the time of the 2015 fish survey. Curly leaf pondweed in Lake Benton was at one time very prolific and covered nearly 100% of the surface water. After chemical (Floridone) treatments from 2005 to 2009 the lake has been returned to undetectable levels of curly leaf pondweed growth in 2015. The lake bottom composition of Lake Benton was mostly gravel, sand, and rubble covered with detritus. The water level of Lake Benton was at normal stage during the summer of 2015 relative to historic observed water levels.

The fishery of Lake Benton is primarily managed for Walleye and secondarily for Black Crappie, Bluegill, Northern Pike, and Yellow Perch. A population assessment was conducted the week of July 27th, 2015 with 4 gill nets and 15 trap nets to assess the managed fish species.


WALLEYE

One hundred and seven Walleye were sampled during the 2015 population assessment. Ninety-two were caught in 4 gill nets and 15 were caught in 15 trap nets for catch rates of 23.0 per gill net and 1.0 per trap net. Fish appeared to be healthy when caught and analysis of length and weight information for each fish verified this. The gill net catch rate was equivalent to the 59 year historical catch rate average of 22.9 per gill net. Additionally, the 2015 gill net catch rate exceeded the expected range of 3.2 to 15.3 per gill net and was equal to the upper expected range value for Windom Area class 41 lakes (23.3 per gill net).

Walleye stocking was changed after the 2005 survey to increase stocking of Walleye fry from every other year to 2 out of every 3 years at a rate of 1,000 fry per acre. Since that change, the catch rate of Walleye in gill nets has remained near or above 15.0 per gill net. In fact, the catch rate since 2010 has remained above 20.0 per gill net over 4 surveys (2010, 2011, 2013, and 2015). The historical catch rate prior to 2010 never exceeded 20 per gill net over two or more surveys in a row. The Walleye population appears to be stable and at a high level never seen before in Lake Benton.

The additional year of stocking coupled with natural reproduction of Walleye is also becoming more regular in Lake Benton. Natural reproduction of Walleye has been verified in each non-stocked year since 2006. Non-stocked years occurred in 2008, 2011, and 2014. Scale samples of the naturally reproduced Walleye contain genetic material and were sent to Dr. Loren Miller (MN DNR researcher and geneticist) at the University of Minnesota. Genetic analysis indicated that the 2008 and 2011 year classes of fish are more closely related to a recently verified southern MN strain of Walleye (Lower Mississippi River Strain, aka Lake Sarah Strain or Canon River Strain) than they are to DNR stocked Walleye (Diamond Lake Strain from Spicer Area Fisheries). This indicates that natural reproduction of a potentially "native" or historically stocked Walleye strain with some kind of survival advantage may be occurring. The 2014 naturally produced group of Walleye has not been analyzed yet, but scale samples will be tested during 2016 to determine their genetic ancestry.

The change in stocking strategy of Walleye coupled with more favorable conditions for natural reproduction since 2006 have led to increased catch rates of Walleye in Lake Benton in DNR surveys. However, the average length of the Lake Benton Walleye has decreased since 2010. Regardless of the decline, healthy Walleye populations can exist with a smaller size structure. The smaller size of Walleye sampled could be due to sampling inefficiencies during the most recent survey when weather was very windy or it could be a result of successful stocking and natural reproduction in recent years leading to larger amounts of smaller fish. Another population assessment will be conducted in 2017 and the Walleye population will be reevaluated. In the meantime, Walleye fry stocking was conducted in the spring of 2015 and will continue in the spring of 2016. A more balanced size structure is anticipated in the near future because 63% of the Walleye sampled in 2015 were between 12 and 15 inches and growth from now until the Summer of 2016 should result in Walleye exceeding 15 inches.


YELLOW PERCH

One hundred and four Yellow Perch were caught in gill nets and trap nets on Lake Benton during 2015. The trap net catch rate of 0.3 per net was within the expected catch rate range of 0.3 to 2.6 per trap net. The gill net catch rate of 25.0 per net exceeded the expected catch rate range of 3.0 to 22.5 per gill net. The Yellow Perch population in Lake Benton is cyclical in nature and commonly fluctuates between periods of low and periods of high catch rates. Lake Benton is mostly devoid of ideal spawning habitat for Yellow Perch except for a few downed trees and some lake bottom areas that can favor spawning. Therefore, when conditions are not exactly right for spawning the result is typically a mediocre or failed reproduction. The 2015 net catch was composed of larger Yellow Perch and didn't have any individuals smaller than 6 inches indicating a potential year class failure or increased predation on smaller Yellow Perch or sampling inefficiencies during high winds. But the Yellow Perch that were caught in the sample indicated a population that has a large size structure with fish in the 8 to 10 inch range. In addition, the health of the Yellow Perch appears to be good. Overall, the Yellow Perch population is dominated by larger fish that are in good condition. This should translate to an ability to fish for an abundant Yellow Perch population during 2016 and 2017.


NORTHERN PIKE

Six Northern Pike were captured in trap nets and gill nets in 2015. The trap net catch rate was 0.1 per net which is less than the Windom Fisheries Management Area expected catch rate range of 0.2 to 1.0 per trap net. The gill net catch rate in 2015 was 1.0 per gill net, less than the statewide expected catch rate range for class 41 lakes (1.2 to 7.8 per gill net) but within the southwest MN catch rate range for class 41 lakes (0 to 1.3 per gill net). The low catch rates were not unexpected due to a lack of spawning habitat for Northern Pike to sustain their population through natural reproduction. Additionally, the last time Northern Pike were stocked was 2006 so the population is aging and decreasing. However, the size structure and the overall health of the Northern Pike population is good. The next stocking of Northern Pike fingerling is scheduled for June 2016 so the population should receive a boost provided MN DNR rearing ponds produce adequate numbers of Northern Pike in 2016. This boost will sustain the low density population of predators that are essential to maintaining a balance in the entire fish community of Lake Benton.


BLACK CRAPPIE

Twelve Black Crappie were caught in gill nets and trap nets combined in 2015. The gill net catch rate was 0.8 per gill net and 0.6 per trap net. Both catch rates for gill nets and trap nets were less than the statewide expected catch rate ranges. All Black Crappie caught were less than 8 inches but the health of each fish was noted as excellent. The low abundance population appears to have been dominated by small fish in 2015 but growth can be fast for crappie. No stocking is advised as Crappie populations are up and down naturally and will increase and decrease in catchability and numbers based on slight changes in habitat or environmental variables (temperature, water quality, water clarity, etc.). The Black Crappie population at the moment appears to be sustaining a small population that should translate to a catchable population by late 2016.


BLUEGILL

Eight Bluegill were sampled in gill nets and trap nets combined. The gill net catch rate was 0.3 per net and the trap net catch rate was 0.5 per trap net. The trap net catch rate is below the statewide low expected catch rate value of 1.1 per trap net. The Bluegill in Lake Benton are most likely larger than 6 inches based on the sample in 2015. Bluegill adults are stocked periodically by the local fish and game club and they appear to be contributing to a low density fish population with most fish between 8 and 10 inches.


OTHER SPECIES

Other species sampled in 2015 include Black Bullhead, Common Carp, and White Sucker.

The Black Bullhead catch rates were within the statewide expected catch rate ranges at 24.8 per gill net and 8.7 per trap net. Historically, they are below the long-term catch rate averages and are at lower than expected abundances, and have been since 2007. Most Black Bullhead were between 8 and 10 inches.

Common Carp catch rates are 0.8 per gill net and 1.4 per trap net, both within their respective expected statewide catch rate ranges. As for Black Bullhead, the Common Carp catch rates are lower than their long-term averages for Lake Benton. Sizes of Common Carp were all over the board but most were adults larger than 16 inches.

The White Sucker gill net catch rate was the highest on record at 50.0 per gill net. The trap net catch rate of White Sucker (1.0 per trap net) was within the expected statewide catch rate range. Most White Sucker were between 11 and 17 inches and should provide a potentially high available forage base for large Walleye and Northern Pike helping the gamefish to have an ability to grow to very large sizes.


SUMMARY

While Lake Benton supports a limited diversity of fish, it is a destination for Walleye anglers in southwestern Minnesota. When the bite is on, anglers should have the opportunity to catch their limit of Walleye in the 13 to 15 inch range with some fish larger than 16 inches as a bonus. To have a chance to catch the big one you need to wet a line, get out there and give it a try in 2016!

Prepared by Nate Hodgins

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre natural lake of lake class 41 located in western Lincoln County. Lake Benton is located nine miles east of the Minnesota-South Dakota border. The city of Lake Benton is located on the southern end of the lake at the intersection of US highways 14 and 75.

The watershed of Lake Benton is primarily composed of agricultural development with roughly 90 percent of the watershed planted in crops or utilized for pasture. Other uses of the Lake Benton watershed include forest/woodlands, grasslands, and municipal. The immediate shoreline surrounding Lake Benton is composed mostly of undeveloped forest or woodland (80%), and grassland (20%); however, some development is present in the Lake Benton city limits. Residentially, 128 cabins or homes were present on Lake Benton in 2006. Recreational use is apparently important on Lake Benton and during this survey a total of 127 boats were observed on or around the perimeter of the lake basin. There were a total of six inlets to Lake Benton; however, there was only a single inlet with a recordable flow (Norwegian Creek) at the time of this survey. Outflows from Lake Benton include Coon Creek, which was flowing at the time of this survey.

Lake Benton has a maximum depth of 9 ft, a secchi depth of 2 ft, and supported vegetation to a depth of 5 ft (based on the 2000 survey). Native aquatic plant species of submergent and emergent vegetation was rare in Lake Benton in 2000. Sago pondweed was the most commonly observed native aquatic vegetation. Conversely, the exotic invasive curly leafed pondweed has been a common aquatic plant species in Lake Benton. Subsequently, the entire Lake Benton water basin had been treated with Fluridone during 2005 and 2006 with additional treatments scheduled annually through 2009 in attempts to chemically control curly leafed pondweed. DNR Ecological Services continues to monitor the aquatic vegetation in Lake Benton annually through the Fluridone treatment years. The shoal water substrate composition of Lake Benton was mostly gravel, sand, and rubble covered with detritus. The water level of Lake Benton was normal during the summer of 2006 relative to historic observed water levels.

The fishery of Lake Benton is primarily managed for walleye and secondarily for black crappie, bluegill, northern pike and yellow perch. A population assessment was conducted during the week of July 17, 2006 using 6 gill nets and 13 trap nets.

Walleye: Lake Benton is managed primarily for walleye. Historically, Lake Benton has provided an exceptional walleye fishery with gill net catches ranging from 13 to 37 fish/net between 1983 and 2003. The abundance of walleye during the 80s and 90s generally was within the current management plan of maintaining a relative abundance above 16 fish/net. However, beginning in 2003, and following a record observed abundance (37 fish/net) of walleye in 2000, the walleye abundance had declined to at or below 10 fish/net. Currently, the abundance of walleye in Lake Benton based on gill netting is below the objective range (? 16 fish/net), but within the range for similar lakes.

During 2006, walleye captured in gill nets ranged in total length from 11.1 to 26.3 inches with a mean length of 18.7 inches. Roughly 70 percent of the walleye >10 inches are also >15 inches, which has been maintained for the past 10 years. The proportion of 15 inch or longer walleye in Lake Benton is above the objective range of 30  50 and indicates that the size structure of walleye in Lake Benton is comprised of a slightly higher proportion of larger fish (? 15 inches) than a population that is considered balanced. Similarly, the proportion of walleye in Lake Benton that are >20 inches total length is also higher than a population considered balanced.

The condition of walleye in Lake Benton is within the objective range and most walleye in the lake are considered plump and in good shape. There was no apparent relationship between walleye condition and length indicating appropriate food availability for the entire walleye population. However, growth of walleye has apparently slowed over the past 10 years based on length at age. Currently walleye obtain quality (? 15 inches) length at about the fourth year of growth. Comparatively, walleye were obtaining quality length between the second and third year of growth as recently as the 2000 survey.

Stocking of walleye in Lake Benton has been through fry stocking on an every-other-year basis. Stocked walleye have contributed to the walleye population during each year except the 2004 stocking, which was not observed during the 2005 survey. Natural reproduction may be present in Lake Benton as evidenced by walleye of ages that were not from stocked years.

Overall, the current abundance and sizes of walleye in Lake Benton indicates that the population is comprised of larger fish and suggests low recruitment of new fish into the population. The potential correlation between walleye growth and lake wide Fluridone treatments should continue to be monitored.

Northern pike: Lake Benton supports a low abundance population of northern pike. Catch rates of northern pike in gill nets have ranged from 0.0 to 2.2 fish/net with an average of 0.7 since 1951. The 2006 survey indicated that northern pike are above the historic average for relative abundance but below the range for similar lakes (1.2  7.8 fish/net). Northern pike captured in gill nets ranged in length from 21.0 to 23.1 inches with an average of 22.0 inches. Overall, the size structure and condition of northern pike in Lake Benton at the time of this survey were acceptable and within desired ranges.

Yellow perch: Historically, yellow perch have been maintained at abundance within the gill net range (3.0  22.5) for lakes similar to Lake Benton. Yellow perch gill net catches have ranged from 1.8 to 336.8 fish/net from 1951 to 2006. However, in 2006 the abundance of yellow perch was only 2.7 fish/gill net and the second lowest abundance ever recorded in Lake Benton. Yellow perch captured in gill nets ranged in length from 9.0 to 11.0 inches with an average length of 9.9 inches. Yellow perch condition was within the objective range. Yellow perch populations naturally fluctuate over time usually peaking when predator abundance (e.g., walleye, northern pike, etc.) is lowest; however, the yellow perch population is currently below objective ranges. Yellow perch rely on submerged vegetation for spawning habitat and the removal of vegetation through Fluridone treatments may negatively impact perch reproduction.

Black crappie and Bluegill: Generally, the black crappie and bluegill abundance in Lake Benton have been maintained within the ranges for similar lakes. However, the abundance based on frame nets of both black crappie (0.5 fish/net) and bluegill (0.2 fish/net) in 2006 were below objective ranges. Black crappie captured in frame nets ranged in length from 4.3 to 10.2 inches with an average length of 8.5 inches. Few bluegills were captured making estimation of mean length difficult. The size structures of each black crappie and bluegill were above that expected of a balanced population. Condition of black crappie and bluegill at the time of this survey was within the objective range. Overall, the black crappie and bluegill populations in Lake Benton are comprised of low abundance and larger individuals that are in good overall condition.

Black bullhead: Black bullhead abundance in Lake Benton has ranged from 2.6 to 285.3 fish/net from 1956 through 2006. Generally, black bullheads have historically been maintained within the normal range (1.3  78.1 fish/net) for lakes similar to Lake Benton with the exception of 1992 during an extraordinarily high frame net catch. However, beginning in 2003 the abundance of black bullhead increased from the historic mean due to the establishment of a very large 2002-year class. During 2006, the black bullhead population was generally only comprised of a single year class with a total length ranging from 7 to 9 inches. The frame net catch of black bullheads has declined during each survey since 2003 and indicates that the abundance of bullheads is declining.

Common carp: The catch of common carp in frame nets has remained steady historically in Lake Benton with the abundance in the lower range compared to similar lakes. During 2006, the frame net catch was 0.7 fish/net and below the historic average of 2.9 fish/net. Maintaining low common carp abundance is important to aid in re-establishing native aquatic vegetation in the lake following the Fluridone treatments to control curly leafed pondweed.

Other species: Other species captured during the 2006 population assessment included green sunfish, largemouth bass, and white sucker.


Summary

In general, the abundance of most fish species in Lake Benton is lower than the historical average based on our netting information. Specifically, walleye are the primary species managed in Lake Benton and the current walleye abundance (10 fish/net) is below our objective range of 16 fish/net. Even though the walleye abundance in Lake Benton is below our objective range, it is still within the range expected for lakes similar to Lake Benton. The DNR attempts to maintain a high abundance of walleye in Lake Benton to aid in controlling black bullhead and other 'rough fish' abundance. Overall, the sizes of walleye in the lake are exceptional with walleye ranging in length from 11 to 26 inches, with a high percentage of the walleye being above 15 inches and even 20 inches. The condition of walleye in Lake Benton is good and there appears to be plenty of food for walleye to eat (e.g., black bullhead), which may hurt your catch rates angling for walleye. Speaking of black bullhead, the abundance of bullheads is very high compared to historical averages. There was a very large year class (fish from a specific years reproduction) developed, most likely from 2002, that is in Lake Benton. So, the population of black bullhead in Lake Benton is mostly all the same age and around 9 inches in length. Therefore, the catch rates of black bullheads in trap nets have declined each of the past 3 surveys as mortality picks away at that year class. Again, maintaining a high walleye abundance aids in controlling the numbers of bullheads even though most lakes in southern Minnesota occasionally have a large year class of bullheads here and there regardless of walleye abundance.

Northern pike numbers have remained relatively consistent among years in Lake Benton with a catch rate of around one fish/net. Because we utilize a passive gear for capture (gill nets and frame nets) we rely on fish to move in order to encounter our sampling gear and be captured. Subsequently, northern pike are not captured very effectively in our sampling gears because we generally survey Lake Benton in mid-July during a time that pike are out in the deepest coolest waters or just are not very active. With that said, Lake Benton can provide good northern pike angling and most pike currently range in length up to 24 inches.

Panfish species such as bluegill, black crappie, and yellow perch are present in Lake Benton. DNR netting suggests that the populations of panfish are at or below the historic averages. Bluegill sizes in Lake Benton are around 9 inches, black crappie from 4 to 10 inches, and yellow perch are near 11 inches in length. Yellow perch numbers in particular were low based on the 2006 survey. This could indicate that the high black bullhead abundance currently in Lake Benton may be inhibiting yellow perch.

The DNR continues to stock about 2.5 million walleye fry every-other-year to maintain consistent year classes. The DNR also plans to continue monitoring the Lake Benton fishery in conjunction with the continued treatment of the lake to control curly leafed pondweed.

Lake Benton has been treated with Fluridone annually since 2005 to help control the exotic invasive curly leafed pondweed. There has been some concern from the public regarding the edibility of fish in Lake Benton given the treatments of the lake with a chemical. Fluridone acts by blocking the carotenoids (yellow, orange, and red pigments) in plants. Chlorophyll, which is used to convert sunlight into food by plants, is protected from sunlight by carotenoids. This is why you will notice plants turning white in the days and weeks following treatment with Fluridone as the sun destroys the unprotected chlorophyll. Once the chlorophyll is destroyed the plants no longer can convert sunlight into the sugars the plants need for energy. The end result is that the plants basically starve to death. This action is limited strictly to plants and since fish or humans do not have chlorophyll there is no apparent harm to either the fish or humans that consume the fish, even immediately after treatment. Therefore, there is no known concern or human health hazard with the consumption of fish from a Fluridone treated body of water, such as Lake Benton.

Enjoy your fishing,

-Prepared by Craig Soupir, NR Fisheries Specialist

Lake Benton is a 2,857-acre, class 41 lake that is adjacent to the City of Lake Benton in Lincoln County. Lake Benton is managed primarily for Walleye and secondarily for Yellow Perch, Northern Pike, Black Crappie, and Bluegill. Since 2006, natural reproduction of Walleye has been documented in each non-stocked year (2008, 2011, and 2014). Nighttime electrofishing was conducted on October 12, 2017 to check for natural reproduction of Walleye because 2017 was a non-stocked year.

Young-of-the year Walleye were captured at a rate of 4.0 per hour electrofishing, which indicates that natural reproduction was very limited or predation of those walleye was high. We typically suspect high predation when we have high numbers of Age 1 and Age 2 walleye in the population, which Lake Benton currently has at this time. The age-0 Walleyes ranged in length from 8.3 to 9.7 inches and averaged 8.9 inches.

Electrofishing for age-0 Walleye was conducted on 26 September 2023 on Lake Benton. Lake Benton was not stocked with walleye fry during 2023, so any age-0 walleye sampled would have been from natural reproduction or emigration. One-hundred-ninety-two (192) age-0 Walleye were sampled during 32 minutes of electrofishing. Sampling was conducted during late day. Fin clips from 50 age-0 walleye were kept and sent for genetic testing to determine ancestry. It was determined that 32.4% of age-0 walleye were Spicer Strain (SPS) and 30.1% were Lower Mississippi Strain (LMS) with the remainder not assigning distinctly to any strain and were a cross of genetic strains. Therefore, including the genetic crosses, Lake Benton is unique in that southern Minnesota strains are extremely dominant and make up nearly the entire 2023 year class. Spicer strain Walleye (Spicer Area Fisheries Office egg take) were last stocked in 2016 with stocking occurring from the early 2000's until 2016. Lower Mississippi Strain (Windom Area Fisheries Office egg take) Walleye have been stocked in Lake Benton since 2018 with spawning size fish (age-3 and older) becoming more common over the past several years. It appears that Lake Benton may contain an increasingly unique walleye population with more and more evidence of natural reproduction during the past 20 years. Since 2005, Lake Benton has a contribution of 20% due to natural reproduction. The 20% is only what can be determined during years where other walleye are not stocked, so the true percentage could actually be greater with natural reproduction adding to the population during years were walleye fry are stocked. More investigation into natural reproduction via genetic testing of year classes caught in gill nets and electrofishing will be done on Lake Benton.
